urn:contentItem:5WKF-WR51-F03R-N4BJ-00000-00Chinese vertical dramas made for phone viewing show the future of mobile video2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisChinese vertical dramas made for phone viewing show the future of mobile videoHenry Sung

Jul 17, 2019( TheNextWeb.com: http://thenextweb.com Delivered by Newstex) Mobile video is a big deal, but you don't need me to tell you that. Big Tech has been fast-moving into the mobile video space for a few[1] years now[2], and recently a slew of mobile-specific content has arrived. Instagram launched IGTV in 2018, and is pushing creators to explore what's possible[3] for mobile video. Netflix introduced vertical 30-second previews[4], and is now experimenting with mobile-first features like vibrating movies[5]. Spotify is releasing vertical music videos[6]. Snap is deliveringplenty of premium mobile video content with its Snap Originals,[7] and hasmoreon the way.[8] But compared to traditional videos which have been around since 1895[9], mobile video is still a newborn baby. And for new parents, a good way to learn parenting is to look at what others are doing. On that note, mobile video producers should direct their attention to a format Chinese media companies have been experimenting with: the vertical drama (竖屏剧; shùpngjù).

https://thenextweb.com/world/2019/07/17/chinese-vertical-dramas-made-for-phone-viewing-show-the-future-of-mobile-video/#iQiyi's Arg DirectorVertical dramas are what Chinese producers call their scripted content made especially for vertical mobile play. Chinese internet giant Tencent first dipped its toes into the vertical drama category in 2018, releasing short romcom series like My Boyfriend-ish Sister[10] (我的男友力姐姐;Wǒ de nnyǒul jiějiě) and My Idiot Boyfriend[11] (我的二货男友; Wǒ de r huò nnyǒu). Soon after, iQiyi, a production company under the other Chinese giant Baidu, released the slice-of-life sitcom Ugh! Life[12]! (生活对我下手了; Shēnghuó du wǒ xishǒule) in the same year. Its sister series Arg Director[13] (导演对我下手了; Dǎoyǎn du wǒ xishǒule), a sketch comedy show exploring the genre tropes from Chinese TV, was released in 2019. Smaller players have also entered the vertical playing field with more modestly-scaled productions. A notable example is Mr Yan Dong! Don't Come Over[14] (颜东先生别过来; Yn dōng xiānshēng bi guòli), a gay romantic series produced by Manman, an app dedicated to digital comicstrips. Popular video apps like Douyin (TikTok's Chinese version) and Kuaishou have begun curating professionally produced, scripted narrative content too. What's remarkable about vertical drama is that it's not just any scripted content cropped for a vertical aspect ratio. These shows are specifically imagined for the mobile screen from the ground up. This is evident in three features they all share.   https://thenextweb.com/world/2019/07/17/chinese-vertical-dramas-made-for-phone-viewing-show-the-future-of-mobile-video/#iQiyi's Arg Director 1. Super short episodesAn episode in a vertical drama is typically between two and five minutes. They're written to deliver each plot-point or punchline as quickly as possible. Before you know it, an episode of Arg Director delivers 10 jokes and then quickly ends, leaving you with an appetite for more. This way, not only is a viewer much more likely to finish an episode, they're more likely to finish a whole season. With the bitesize episodes being snackable AND bingeable, vertical dramas lock in the viewer's attention with the same intensity as a tub of popcorn. In the battle formobile audience's fragmented attention, longform content can't compete: this is the Popcorn League (Note that as the vertical format requires you hold the phone with one hand, it's taking one hand away from the actual popcorn, thus even winning half of THAT fight).   https://thenextweb.com/world/2019/07/17/chinese-vertical-dramas-made-for-phone-viewing-show-the-future-of-mobile-video/#iQiyi's Ugh! Life! 2. Vertical is treated as a genreThe great majority of vertical dramas released so far have a comedic dimension. This is, of course, by design: comedy is a genre known for conveying gratification in short bursts, and comedies typically have an emphasis on actors' facial reactions. Both of these elements are a great fit for mobile. Just as television has properties that suit certain content better than feature films, so does vertical mobile video. Namely, the medium is good for a lot of intense, fast-paced, and personal moments. Specific narrative devices, such as characters' internal dialogues or a very abrupt turn of events, would be awkward and out of place when used excessively in longform storytelling. However, these devices are the typical narrative building blocks in iQiyi's sitcom Ugh Life!, where characters in everyday situations often find extraordinary things happening around them, such as time-traveling, mind-control, or extremely disappointing blind dates. This doesn't mean the vertical mobile format is only fit for comedies, but rather that when Chinese producers ideated their vertical dramas, the medium's innate rhythm was accounted for.   https://thenextweb.com/world/2019/07/17/chinese-vertical-dramas-made-for-phone-viewing-show-the-future-of-mobile-video/#A pilot episode for the show 'Cursed to be Single' (单身狗的诅咒; Dānshēn gǒu de zǔzhòu) 3. A fragmented visual languageA combination of split screens, swipes, and quick cuts dominate the visual language of the vertical drama. This is, of course, a style appropriate for the short episodes and fast comedic rhythm of these shows. But it also allows each moment on screen to contain more information. While the vertical mobile video has very limited visual space for spatial context and mise-en-scne, it compensates by literally pushing double or triple the amount of visual information into focus. This results in a visually fragmented viewing experience that is nonetheless fluid and dynamic. We can also consider the mobile screen's form factor. The large film screen, through its overwhelming size, attempts to immerse the cinema-goer in another world. The mobile screen, which in this sense is the opposite of film, doesn't concern itself with immersion, but rather provides a tiny surreal portal into the universe of its content. It is this surreal distinction of the small mobile display from its real world surroundings that allows viewers to accept its supernatural visual language: faster, denser, and more information-rich than the real world can offer. It's important to note these elements are not particular to a Chinese context, but rather they're particular to the vertical mobile format. If we look at the Snap Originals released recently, we can actually find traces of the same features too. Mobile video is a new medium, but video creatives on both sides of the planet are beginning to figure out the things that work. urn:contentItem:5WSS-35R1-DYTY-C2S4-00000-00Chips to make you a genius - if you put your mind to it2019-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisBUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESSPg. 8Chips to make you a genius - if you put your mind to itNatasha Bernal

Have you ever wanted to be more intelligent, stronger or have a superpower? The possibilities are hidden inside our minds, scientists claim - as long as we can develop the technology to unlock it.

Some of Britain's top scientists are competing against the giants of Silicon Valley to create devices that could turn the average person into a genius, let us control electronics using our minds or free people with mobility difficulties.

The possibilities of mind-reading technology are endless: from personalised games and films that read your brainwaves, to helping paralysed people to move their limbs independently. The big question is who will get there first. US and EU governments are pouring hundreds of billions into efforts to map the brain.

Silicon Valley has research budgets to match. Last month, Facebook said it had developed a prototype for a headset that can transfer a person's thoughts directly onto a computer screen. The company says the new technology could help people with paralysis communicate, although it is unclear how the invention, described by founder Mark Zuckerberg as the "ultimate communication technology" will make it into Facebook's services.

Meanwhile, Tesla founder and tech billionaire Elon Musk announced he had gone one step further. His side project Neuralink unveiled plans to implant computer chips in people's brains that could treat diseases and enable superhuman intelligence.

But both these developments are still years away, and the UK tech scene's approach is far less theoretical. One East London start-up, Myndplay, has developed brainwave-reading technology that aims to create a generation of "Jedi mind warriors", according to founder Tre Azam.

The company has already worked with advertising giant Ogilvy to find the algorithm to measure pleasure, and has run a project with G4S to help prisoners control their tempers.

The technology, used as a headband or paired with virtual reality headsets, allows people to peek inside their own mind and watch how it reacts to external stimulus. This, Azam says, will allow people to learn more about themselves and become capable of increased levels of concentration or calm at will. Myndplay says its technology could also be used to control devices, replacing touchscreens or voice control systems. In a prototype released last week, the company proved small objects such as a fan or a lightswitch can be controlled using the power of concentration.

Ni2o, a University of Oxford spin-off, is close to commercialising a chip that could provide a less invasive alternative to deep brain stimulation to treat Parkinson's and other diseases. It could lower the cost of treatment from $23,000 (£19,000) to less than $2,000 (£1,650). The chip, smaller than a grain of rice, would be implanted in areas of the brain where clinical treatment is needed, sending tiny jolts of electrical energy to stimulate parts of the brain in response to neural impulses, allowing people to control their movements with far more ease.

"A lot of research communities want a machine to be better than a human or augmenting a human. I saw there was a gap, and a necessity, for restoring human dignity," says Dr Newton Howard, a professor in Oxford's computational neuroscience lab. "Each person we are able to treat is a success. It breaks my heart that we don't have a solution today." He admits the same technique could be used to stimulate the brain and turbocharge our intelligence. "You can become a genius depending on the areas you are targeting and frequencies you operate in."

However, just as one can turn on the genius tap, this technology could be exploited in the reverse, blocking people's thoughts and dumbing them down. We should be concerned about the ethics of this technology, he argues. Last year reports emerged of workers in China being hooked up to mind-reading technology in an effort to tell whether they were feeling rage.

Researchers have also expressed concern that Big Tech could not only rewrite the way this technology is used, but scare regulators into blocking developments that would make a positive difference.

"What keeps me awake at night is the thought that this could be developed by Musk and Zuckerberg," one researcher from a top UK university says. "Their motives are weird, they know little about the topics that they jump into."

Dr Howard says one of his fears is Big Tech will "turn things sour for everyone. Regulators might say 'We haven't been able to regulate you on social media, how do we trust augmenting your reign and allowing you into the human brain?' The damage is for everyone else that is well intended."

urn:contentItem:5Y1C-T241-F0J6-J0MW-00000-00Chook fund beats the pack again2020-01-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisCHANTICLEERPg. 40Chook fund beats the pack againTony Boyd

Crowing about your super fund returns is a dangerous game that will one day end in tears. But readers keep asking for regular updates on the Chook super fund so here goes.

The 2019 calendar year was out of the ordinary for most super funds, according to analysis published on Friday by consulting firm Chant West. It said the median growth fund was up 14.7 per cent in 2019, the best calendar year return since 2013 and the seventh best in the entire 27½-year history of compulsory superannuation.

"Even the worst performer in our growth category returned a healthy 10.5 per cent, which was nearly 9 per cent above the rate of inflation," Chant West said.

"Growth funds are those that have a 61 to 80 per cent allocation to growth assets and are the ones in which the majority of Australians are invested."

The trustees established the Chook super fund in 2012 to take control of their retirement savings and have greater flexibility in the transition to retirement phase. Money was shifted out of other funds including Media Super.

The fund's net return after fees for the past six months was 7.56 per cent and 26.65 per cent for the 2019 calendar year. The fee of 1 per cent of assets covers advice and accounting.

The recent performance compares well with the growth funds in the Chant West database, which showed returns of 5.8 per cent for six months and 20.8 per cent for the year. Chant West said high growth funds had returns of 5.3 per cent for six months and 17.6 per cent for the full year.

The accompanying graphic breaks down the results by asset class. The asset mix has since changed with 7 per cent of assets now in alternatives.

The strong Australian equities result for 2019 was helped by the surge in value of CSL, ResMed and Genworth. The performance numbers include income and growth.

Genworth did extremely well because of the amount paid in dividends. In the six months to December it paid out 54.9¢ a share in special and ordinary dividends. Chanticleer had written previously about Genworth's ability to generate excess capital and distribute it as dividends.

The fund's investments are made through a combination of decisions by the trustees and the fund's adviser, Charlie Viola from Pitcher Partners Sydney Wealth Management. All the poor performers and some of the best performers in the latest six months were chosen by the trustees including Class, Splunk, Toyota, Rhipe, Jupiter Mines and Goodman Group.

The fund's trustees and Viola agree that shares in quality companies that deliver profits through the business cycle regardless of market volatility will remain sound long-term investments.

Viola says the forces within super's legislative and regulatory system are increasingly pushing trustees and advisers to recommend lower exposure to shares through "lifecycle" super options that become more conservative as the beneficiaries get older.

The surge in share prices over the past few years has ensured most super fund members are overweight equities and will be cutting exposures if they adopt the lifecycle approach favoured by regulators and the trustees of public offer funds.

If markets tumble this pressure to slash equity weightings in super fund portfolios will increase. But Viola questions the wisdom of super fund members meeting an arbitrary risk benchmark that forces them to sell quality assets that generate reliable, fully franked income through the economic cycle. "If I think CBA will keep generating profit, and earnings per share (EPS) of say $4.90 plus and dividends of $4.30, do I care if it's worth $84 or $74?" Viola asks.

"Remember, the single dollar I spent on CBA when it was $84, still generates a better return at $74 than cash ever will as long as I don't sell it."

Over the past five years, CBA shares have fluctuated between a high in March 2015 of $96.32 to a low in October 2018 of $65.27 to Friday's close of $84. Over the same period the bank has paid out $21.31 in dividends. Its yield is 5.1 per cent and 7.28 per cent when grossed up for tax paid.

CBA was once in the Chook super fund, as was Westpac Banking Corp, but both stocks were sold in November 2018 in favour of ANZ. The Westpac decision proved smart and the CBA and ANZ decisions less so.

The fund's exposure to international equities is a combination of directly held shares and managed funds. The best directly held stocks have been Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and CME Group.

Two lessons learned in 2019 were that actively managed international funds can complement each other and index funds are a good low-cost option.

Loftus Peak and Magellan have been outstanding active managers over the past five years with the Loftus Peak Global Change Portfolio (which has a longer tenure under the current manager than the Loftus Peak Global Disruption Fund) returning 16.98 per cent per annum over five years and Magellan Global Fund returning 12.9 per cent per annum. Over seven years Magellan's return has been 18.4 per cent per annum.

At this stage the Chook super fund has done well with a three-year return of 16.17 per cent per annum and 14.54 per cent over five years. But the fund is one market crash away from being a feather duster.

The asset allocation at year end was Australian equities 42.17 per cent, international equities 39.56 per cent, property 5.59 per cent, fixed interest 1.82 per cent, cash 2.5 per cent, hybrids 0.19 and alternatives 8.18 per cent. The alternatives were added at year end so there is no meaningful period for measuring performance.

Banks can't do tech transformations

Banks and insurance companies have a serious problem with institutional investors after failing to deliver financial benefits from much touted digital transformation programs.

Shareholders lack confidence in the management of financial services companies when it comes to tech, according to Oliver Wyman's State of the Financial Services Industry 2020. This is an annual publication timed to coincide with the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

Damning fund manager comments about the failure of large-scale digital transformation projects in financial services were picked up by Oliver Wyman during an investor sentiment survey in November last year.

"There is very little evidence of investments improving banks' operating profitability," one fund manager told Oliver Wyman and consulting firm Procensus.

The survey found that only 25 per cent of investors are confident digital transformation strategies will be effective.

There is no geographic sourcing for the comments but Chanticleer suspects Australian institutions would hold similar views after watching as banks promised benefits from digital transformations and then, in most cases, failed to deliver.

"With no comparable data points, investors understandably struggle to make sense of digital transformation, technology, and investment," the Oliver Wyman report said.

"As one fund manager put it to us, "It is all jumbled up - IT replacement, automation, customer journeys ... There seem to be some wins but it's anecdotal."

"Investors end up being outright sceptical, or discounting change programs and the long-term benefits of digital technology. In the first half of 2019, European banks mentioned "digital" in 98 per cent of their external communications, compared to only 27 per cent of analyst research reports."

While investors are unconvinced about investment plans put forward by banks and insurers, they do see upside from digital technology implementation in the form of cost cutting.

Oliver Wyman concludes that banks wishing to transform themselves need to communicate better with shareholders, provide clear and measurable metrics and face up directly to the threat from fintechs and big tech.
