(1) To cite a policy paper by the Paris-based Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Ferencz and Gonzales 2019,4), "Information and communications technology services form the backbone of the digital economy by providing the necessary network infrastructure and underpinning the digitisation of other types of services. Once services activities can be digitised, they can be transferred across electronic networks ... Therefore policies that encourage competition and investment in high-speed networks are essential to unlock the full potential of the digital transformation."

(2) As exemplified by the Creative Canada Vision issued by the Department of Canadian Heritage (Joly 2017), which provides "a roadmap that focuses on supporting our creators, delivering their content to domestic and international audiences, and ensuring that there is always a space for Canadians to connect through our stories." It offers a policy framework divided into three pillars: 1. "Invest in Canadian creators, cultural entrepreneurs and their stories"; 2. "Promote discovery and distribution [of products from these Canadian creators]"; and 3. "Strengthen public broadcasting and local news."

(3) Under section 14.1 of the Investment Canada Act, a cultural business is "a Canadian business that carries on any of the following activities, namely, (a) the publication, distribution or sale of books, magazines, periodicals or newspapers in print or machine readable form, other than the sole activity of printing or typesetting of books, magazines, periodicals or newspapers, (b) the production, distribution, sale or exhibition of film or video recordings, (c) the production, distribution, sale or exhibition of audio or video music recordings, (d) the publication, distribution or sale of music in print or machine readable form, or (e) radio communication in which the transmissions are intended for direct reception by the general public, any radio, television and cable television broadcasting undertakings and any satellite programming and broadcast network services."

(4) Netflix seems willing to make public the amounts it spends by country, perhaps as a way to differentiate itself vis-a-vis powerful emerging rivals in these markets (see Sweeney and Conlan 2019).

(5) As von Finckenstein (2017) notes: "Any review of communications has to include the Radiocommunications Act which presently governs spectrum management and wireless communications. All communications, regardless of mode, should be covered by one communications act. The present division between wireline, wireless and cable communications predates the digital revolution and makes no sense in the age of the internet."

(6) For a reflection on the current state of social capital in Canada, see Valpy (2013).

(7) As well, many cultural products, especially audio-visual items and books available digitally, exhibit key characteristics of "public goods," defined as goods that can be enjoyed by more than one person at the same time at no additional cost per person, beyond the sunk cost of making the initial product, and for which it is difficult to exclude anyone from enjoying. Given that pricing in private markets is based on marginal cost, the public good might not be produced without government support of these sunk costs (Payne 2003,6-8; Grant and Wood 2004, Appendix B). Indeed, they share these characteristics with knowledge generated by R&D spending.

(8) And even if these positive externalities--that is, social benefits in addition to the private benefits accruing to those that might receive a subsidy--could be quantified, taxing other activities to subsidize cultural activities creates a deadweight economic loss, and so the perceived public benefits of cultural activities should at least compensate for that loss.

(9) Thus, in its opening two paragraphs, the 2019-20 departmental plan of the Department of Canadian Heritage states: "The Government ot Canada is committed to promoting Canada's artists and creative and cultural industries ... Canadian Heritage and its portfolio organizations play a vital role in the ... economic life of Canadians. Arts, culture and heritage represent $53.8 billion in the Canadian economy and more than 650,000 jobs" (Canada 2019a, 2).

(10) As the glowing description of international success by Canadian artists and the announcement of a first Creative Export Strategy as part of the Creative Canada Initiative made clear (Joly 2017).

(11) In many cases, exposing foreign audiences as well--for example, through the benefits that can accrue to Canadians generally from cultural diplomacy or cultural tourism in Canada, the scale of cultural activity that export success can enable, or a strong Canada "brand."

(12) The Canada United StatesMexico Agreement that is meant to supersede the NAFTA, but is not yet in force, also includes a cultural exemption.

(13) For rules on the deductibility of advertising expenses with periodicals or broadcasters, see Canada, Justice Laws Website, at https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/i-3.3/page-17.html.

(14) "Pirate'TPTV providers, as the name implies, operate outside of and in competition with regulated broadcasters and owners or licencees of content.

(15) On sales taxes as they apply to foreign-owned digital businesses, see Wyonch (2017). Regarding income taxes, what constitutes a fair share of taxes to be paid in any given country by a multinational company that books its net income in lower-tax jurisdictions is currently the subject of negotiations under the "Base erosion and profit shifting" initiative at the OECD, which aim to conclude by 2020.

(16) For a list of these programs, see Canada, "Funding--Culture, history and sport," online at https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/funding.html.

(17) A point prominently made by Heritage Minister Joly (2017).

(18) However, the cornucopia of US programs that have emerged since the late 1990s actually started as a response to "runaway" film productions attracted by Canadian film production incentives. In such tit-for-tat situations, a more efficient outcome might be achieved if everyone stopped subsidizing.

(19) Canadian newspapers have lost 96 percent of their advertising revenues since 2008 (Wells 2017).

(20) The panel has proposed a mechanism administered by the Canada Revenue Agency that relies on objective criteria as far as possible for the receipt of these funds.

(21) Thus , as Dachis and Schwanen (2016,15), note, II Postino, Like Waterfor Chocolate, Shakespeare in Love, Priscilla Queen of the Desert and Fargo, which many associate culturally with Italy, Mexico, England, Australia, and the United States, respectively, were released by companies based in another country.

(22) It is certainly possible to screen these investors for their good business experience and good character and integrity, as one would screen applicants for a banking licence, for example.

(23) Heritage Canada considers whether the investment will be "promoting the creation, dissemination and preservation of diverse Canadian content; cultural participation and engagement, fostering and strengthening connections among Canadians; and active citizenship and civic participation" (Facey and Krane 2017,52). Note that, unlike FDI rules applying to other businesses, Heritage Canada requires undertakings by a foreign investor to be made in perpetuity (53).

(24) See, for example, a recent exchange in the House of Commons over the paying off of 68 employees by Quebec broadcaster TVA, which the company blamed on unfair competition from "web giants," in which the Canadian heritage minister said that the loss of even just one job was a tragedy, "particularly when it affects the culture and communications sector." Available online at https://openparliament.ca/debates/2019/6/5/ pablo-rodriguez-1/.

(25) A useful overview of why cultural products are not like "ordinary commodities," requiring special attention from competition authorities, copyright rules, and the role of the advertising market as discussed below is provided Grant and Wood (2004), Appendix B.

(26) Webopedia defines search engine optimization as "a methodology of strategies, techniques and tactics used to increase the amount of visitors to a website by obtaining a high-ranking placement in the search results page of a search engine"; see https://www.webopedia.eom/TERM/S/SEO.html.

(27) As with current support programs such as tax credits, certain genres such as pornography would be made ineligible.

(28) Triple j brands itself "the place for the best new music from around Australia &c the world"; see https://www.abc.net.au/triplej/.

urn:contentItem:5WNB-BHH1-DXY4-X058-00000-00Chris Hughes Worked to Create Facebook. Now, He Is Working to Break It Up.2019-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYChris Hughes Worked to Create Facebook. Now, He Is Working to Break It Up.Steve Lohr

Mr. Hughes has joined two leading academics to argue to government officials that Facebook has engaged in anticompetitive behavior for almost a decade.

Chris Hughes used to huddle with Mark Zuckerberg in a Harvard dorm room building Facebook from scratch. Now, he’s huddling with regulators to explain why Facebook needs to be broken up.

In recent weeks, Mr. Hughes has joined two leading antitrust academics, Scott Hemphill of New York University and Tim Wu of Columbia University, in meetings with the Federal Trade Commission, the Justice Department and state attorneys general. In those meetings, the three have laid out a potential antitrust case against Facebook, Mr. Wu and Mr. Hemphill said.

For nearly a decade, they argue, Facebook has made “serial defensive acquisitions” to protect its dominant position in the market for social networks, according to slides they have shown government officials. Scooping up nascent rivals, they assert, can allow Facebook to charge advertisers higher prices and can give users worse experience.

Mr. Hughes’s involvement stands out because few founders have gone on to argue for the dismantling of their company. As the scrutiny of the world’s biggest tech companies has intensified in the last year, many of the complaints about them have come from competitors or academics.

On Wednesday, Facebook announced that the F.T.C. had started an antitrust investigation into the company. The Justice Department has also started a broad antitrust review of the technology industry, as have lawmakers. And on Thursday, some state attorneys general met with the Justice Department to discuss competition in the industry.

It is unclear just what role Mr. Hughes, who left Facebook more than a decade ago and has become increasingly critical of Facebook in public, is playing in the pitches to regulators. In the slide presentation, a “Who We Are” page lists Mr. Hughes as the third member of the group. The page concludes with the bullet point, “Speaking only for ourselves, not a client.”

But Mr. Hughes could, for example, provide investigators with leads to current and former company employees and competitors to interview or subpoena. A partly redacted copy of the slides was provided to The New York Times, with names of the people to interview blacked out. Mr. Wu and Mr. Hemphill have shared the redacted version of the slides with some other antitrust experts. One of them, who asked not to be identified, sent it to The Times.

Neither Mr. Hemphill nor Mr. Wu would discuss Mr. Hughes’s involvement, other than to confirm he attended the presentations.

“He has been an important contributor to thinking about these issues,” Mr. Hemphill said.

Mr. Hughes declined to comment, as did Facebook.

Mr. Hughes, who made hundreds of millions of dollars from his time at Facebook, has become an outspoken critic of the company’s market power and the need for the government to take action. In a lengthy Op-Ed article for The Times in May, he wrote, “We are a nation with a tradition of reining in monopolies, no matter how well-intentioned the leaders of these companies may be.”

Mr. Hughes went on to describe the power held by Facebook and its leader Mr. Zuckerberg, his former college roommate, as “unprecedented.” He added, “It is time to break up Facebook.”

The narrative from the two academics and Mr. Hughes in their presentation is that Facebook, founded in 2004, succeeded in its earlier years by simply outdoing its competitors, like Myspace, by providing a superior social network including fewer ads and promises of protecting users’ privacy.

But by 2010, Facebook was scrambling to adapt to the shift to smartphone computing and the rise of new social network services, like photo sharing. The company’s response, the presentation says, was its program to buy upstart rivals. The biggest deals were for Instagram, the photo sharing service, for $1 billion in 2012, and WhatsApp, the messaging service, for $19 billion in 2014.

At a House antitrust subcommittee hearing last week, a Facebook executive, when asked to name its rivals, hesitated and did not offer a list. Mr. Wu, who also testified, said, “Facebook can’t name its competitors because they bought them.”

But in his written testimony, the executive, Matt Perault, director of public policy at Facebook, listed an array of competitors, including Snapchat, Telegram, Twitter and YouTube. And he described major acquisitions of companies like WhatsApp and Instagram as “investments in innovation,” new services for consumers that Facebook strengthened and expanded with money and resources.

The theory in the presentation by the two academics and Mr. Hughes is that an acquisition strategy can be an illegal tactic to shield a monopoly from competition. An upstart company, they say, need not be a full-fledged competitor at the time of the purchase, merely a potential threat.

The antitrust precedents, they say, stretch back to Standard Oil, which was built with a string of corporate purchases over decades, before the government broke it up in 1911.

“There is a direct connection between the conduct and the remedy — undo the acquisition,” Mr. Hemphill said in an interview.

The professors and Mr. Hughes are not alone in focusing on Facebook’s company-buying campaign. In March, Representative David Cicilline, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the House antitrust subcommittee, wrote to the F.T.C., urging the agency begin an investigation of Facebook.

His first suggested line of inquiry was the social network’s acquisition campaign. “It is clear that allowing Facebook to purchase Instagram and WhatsApp has deprived users of critical competition,” Mr. Cicilline wrote.

Whether the F.T.C. will pursue the company-buying line of investigation is uncertain. The agency’s investigations, which can last months or years, are largely conducted in secret. A representative for the F.T.C. declined to comment.

But antitrust experts say it may be the most promising target of inquiry, focused on a handful of acquisitions rather than a broad review of the company’s conduct in general.

“It is a plausible theory, and it has the elements of an antitrust case,” said Gene Kimmelman, a former senior antitrust official in the Justice Department.

But the key, Mr. Kimmelman said, would be assembling evidence to show that Facebook conducted an intentional campaign to buy companies regarded as future threats, even if they were fledgling start-ups at the time. And then, he said, the agency would want to be able to demonstrate economic harm, like higher prices for advertisers and degraded service for users.

“This is not an easy case,” said Mr. Kimmelman, a senior adviser at the consumer group Public Knowledge.

Steve Lohr covers technology and economics. He was a foreign correspondent for a decade, and in 2013, he was part of the team awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Explanatory Reporting. @SteveLohr Kevin Roose contributed reporting.

urn:contentItem:5T6W-CCH1-JDPT-T0D3-00000-00CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, GABELLI FUNDS IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisCHRIS MARANGI, CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, GABELLI FUNDS IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.

September 6, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, GABELLI FUNDS

ABRAMOWICZ: Let's ask someone else. Chris Marangi, Gabelli Funds co-chief investment officer, joining us here in our 11.30 studios.

Chris, should we care about this?

MARANGI: Well, yesterday was a real three-ring circus in Washington between the Kavanaugh hearings, the op-ed and these hearings.

ABRAMOWICZ: A normal day.

MARANGI: A normal day. And this comes on the context of course of Trump going after Google on Twitter and Bernie Sanders introducing the Stop BEZOS Act. So big tech is a, one could say, under siege.

ABRAMOWICZ: But it has been for a while.

MARANGI: It has been.

ABRAMOWICZ: I mean is there anything that kind of came out yesterday that really --

MARANGI: No, I don't think so.

ABRAMOWICZ: OK.

MARANGI: And I think the fact that Google didn't show up and had a little placard on their empty chair was indicative of what they think of these hearings. But I think ultimately, listen, radio was regulated this medium in 1934 --

FERRO: Yes.

MARANGI: -- over the post-World War II era, lots of regulations in place to limit the voice of any particular broadcast television network owner. And we're just catching up now in the internet age.

And so there will be more regulation, more requirements on the part of the internet companies and that's going to have a cause associated with it.

FERRO: Why don't we celebrate in the company as successful as Amazon in this country? Why don't politicians celebrating this? This is a huge success story, the envy of most of the world.

MARANGI: It is, but it's a big company with a lot of influence and those companies tend to be targeted by politicians. So, interestingly, obviously, that it comes from the left and, you know --

ABRAMOWICZ: And the right.

MARANGI: And the right, which is what's makes it interesting.

ABRAMOWICZ: Well, you know, you mentioned Google, you mentioned that little placard and how they felt about the hearings. Google shares were actually down really a percent ahead of the open today.

MARANGI: Yes.

ABRAMOWICZ: Facebook and Twitter were actually flat. Do you think that that's significant or is it just sort of noise?

MARANGI: I think that's noise at this point. You know, currently, Google survived the privacy regulation regime in Europe pretty well. And I think the end game here is that the companies with scale like Google and Facebook and even Twitter are going to be the ones who were best able to put into systems to comply with whatever Washington wants. And they're going to be further entrenched by regulation.

FERRO: Chris, you help run Gabelli Funds, that's a lot of money. When you look at the tech sector right now, is there any reason why you wouldn't allocate capital to that sector based on a risk of regulation somewhere somehow in the future?

MARANGI: Well, listen, you know, I think it is just one element of the things that we look at. You know, we invest -- we've invested for many, many years, decades in the cable sector. And the biggest risk for the cable sector, the distribution industry has been always will be regulation. And that's just something that you have to digest and see if it's accounted for in the multiples.

ABRAMOWICZ: So right now, given the fact that you have a lot of big analysts saying things look a little hetty (ph) (INAUDIBLE) off the table, what's the biggest opportunity that you see right now?

MARANGI: Yes. So, listen, you know, the extended FANG, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, Microsoft and Apple, are collectively 4.4 trillion, it's like 15% of the S&P, they've accounted for about half of the gains in the S&P so far this year.

You know, those companies I think in aggregate are probably a little bit ahead of themselves. Among them, there are probably better buys like, in my view, Google than say Amazon.

But, you know, beyond that, we have other areas that we look at. We like the cable sector. We think there's going to be consolidation amongst broadcast television networks. That's an interesting area amongst others.

FERRO: Chris Marangi, great to catch up with you today.

MARANGI: Thank you.

FERRO: Thanks for dropping by in the studio. Gabelli Funds co-CIO.

END

July 30, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS

KEENE: To the media update, we're thrilled that Chris Marangi is with us with Gabelli, as we look at media. And of course, Chris, to explain this with a value investment proposition of Mario Gabelli and your team, you've always been in media. How much of a value is Cable TV after the Fox, Disney, Comcast soap opera?

MARANGI: Good morning, Tom and Jonathan, great to be here. Yes, the Cable companies Comcast, Charter, amongst others are a bargain today, more of a bargain than they were before, let's say, a counter bit for Fox. These are good catch willing entities (ph) recurring cash or the recurring cash flow to shareholders and that's why we like them.

KEENE: Comcast did that shift from huge build out to use of cash. On the Bloomberg, their five-year dividend growth as a lofty 4.22 percent. I'm assuming they can sustain that, but can they actually deliver double-digit dividend growth as the cash flow that persistent?

MARANGI: Yes. The return on capital in the cash flow are growing substantially as the business make shifts from video where they're giving up 60 cents in every dollar to the content companies to broadband where they're keeping that money. And have a lot of pricing power (ph).

KEENE: What's interesting here folks, as we were talking with Craig Moffett in MoffettNathanson with us, really important work on Comcast recent than Marangi is sort of on what's called the buy side which is he's actually making portfolio decisions in acquiring shares as well. If Comcast and Cable is cheap, what's rich in media?

MARANGI: Well you point statistically to the same stocks obviously and there's been sort of saying anti-thing (ph) trade when the (INAUDIBLE) are strong. Some of the traditional media companies tend to be weak. I think that's starting to breakdown a little bit. But, you know, it doesn't mean that Google and Netflix and others don't have outstanding businesses. Netflix, in particularly just, you know, appears to trade at a -- with a minimal margin of safety.

FERRO: Yes. It thought it was interesting last week, Chris, that the outperformance came from the old economy equities and the underperformance came from the technology stocks. And I just wonder whether that's one off weak or whether we're starting to a transitions where worldwide can build some confidence around what's happening in the global economy as Europe prepares to have stabilized China that appears to be shifting towards the easing then we have that great growth here in the United States in a second quarter.

MARANGI: Yes, I think that's an interesting point, Jonathan. I think the big tech names were viewed as safe havens in some ways as growth elsewhere starting this. So, you know, I think as we see a little bit of stabilization, the trend to value should persist.

FERRO: Chris, the trend to value has been a right difficult one to buy into --

MARANGI: It's been a long time.

FERRO: -- over the last year. And many of our listeners have heard that again and again and again over the last couple of years. Why is it different this time?

MARANGI: Well we're hoping it's different this time. And, you know, in the end, we think that value will always went out. And, you know, kind of a -- the good place is to be with maybe a choppy (INAUDIBLE) environment but a stable economic environment.

FERRO: Does that leave financials, Chris?

MARANGI: It should. You know, every time we watch the curve and what's happening with the funding in the curve, I think that's been a little bit of an issue but, yes, the financials again statistically look for a two-pair.

FERRO: It's something that's dominated psychology, is it dominated profitability? And I'm talking about the yield curve here, Chris. Has it dominated profitability because I didn't see it, will it?

MARANGI: No, I think, you know, the banks are able to make money if they're in a better regulatory situation than they have been a long time. They'll return a lot more capital to shareholders. So, you know, I think maybe we're overly focused on the shape of the curve.

KEENE: OK, we're overly focused on the shape of the curve, but it's determinant to some extend forward. What about the shape of nominal GDP? I mean, if this is -- if this GDP is good as it gets in an abs (ph) way, what abs (ph) in the Chris Marangi world, the revenues ab?

MARANGI: Yes. So, you know, we've been talking about actually margins for years. And, you know, margins just continue to go up as if we continue to defined companies -- continue to define ways to save money. Obviously, where they seem from earnings, the first two weeks has been increased cost, ample (ph) cost, steel, energy, labor freight (ph). And so we're starting to see some of those sciences inflation which may impact margins. But, you know, we could get into another gear where we see an increase in productivity again.

FERRO: Well Chris, at this conversation with Jeff Rosenberg of BlackRock on Friday and we kept asking this question, is this good as it gets and it may will be the highest rate of growth for any given quarter for this administration. But I think a bigger question, and this is something that Jeff was pushing ever at BlackRock, is whether we've broken out into a higher trend growth, the way from low twos (ph) and something close to the three. Do you have the confidence that we've done that, Chris?

MARANGI: You know, we're bottom up guys and we look at individual companies and we have companies that we listen to on these earnings costs and, you know, they see, for the most part, pretty clear skies ahead. You know, absence some of these ample (ph) cost and absence some of the risk of trade wars. But the consumer seems to be in good shape. Housing is OK and, you know, globally, you know, seeing some pick up.

FERRO: It's funny that we've just had a quarter of not 4 percent and I've heard so many people talking about where do we get our recession at some point back in the next year or early 2020. I've heard a lot of people discussed trade wars and then Carapello (ph) come out this morning raises fuller (ph) guidance. Fuller (ph) guidance raise in the quarter that was dominated by discussions about trade wars and tariffs. How do you reconcile these two things, Chris?

MARANGI: Well, you know, make farmers great again, I guess is the hat that I saw. And, you know, that certainly helps somebody agricultural companies. And, you know, the global demand is there.

KEENE: Jon, I think that's a really important insight.

MARANGI: Great to catch up with you, Chris, of Gabelli Funds, Co-Chief Investment Officer.

(BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5T6W-CCH1-JDPT-T0C4-00000-00CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisCHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.

September 6, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS

FU: Now, joining us here in New York is Chris Marangi, he is Gabelli Funds Co-CIO. And Chris, we were just talking about what's happening in Washington and how that's eating up all of the attention, sucking up all the oxygen there. As an investor, we know that when the president tend to get cornered, and it's not just this president, any president, they tend to look for something else, they look for distractions, they look for something to focus their energy on. Do you expect or anticipate unexpected headlines on trade on North Korea that could come out and change the scope of where we are headed?

MARANGI: Well, administration in turmoil is probably a headline you could've applied in any point in the last 18 months. And what we're focused on is two months from now. Today is September 6, November 6 of the elections in the U.S. So a lot of this is noise, it will focus on the election and I think the expectation at this point is that the Democrats will at least take the House, the Senate is up for grabs and historically divided government has been good for the markets. And so whether it's people inside the administration or other branches of government modulating the impulses of the executive, that's generally viewed positively by the market.

FU: So as an investor, do you look for people within the administration and indeed the President himself to make the decisions that would be good for markets, for the business environment leading up to the midterms because that's where they want to keep the focus on a strong economy?

MARANGI: Yes, that would be smart of the president. I think -- but I think the president will between now and Election Day probably appeal to his base and, yes, I would expect some headlines about trade and immigrations. Somebody -- but on issues on that election.

FU: But resolutions on those?

MARANGI: I doubt that anything gets resolved. We have of course also the --

FU: Right, thanks so much --

LACQUA: Go ahead Chris.

MARANGI: Yes, obviously -- you know, obviously there are other things going on in Washington was a bit of a three ring circus yesterday between the Kavanaugh hearing and the social media hearings.

So, you know, obviously we'll look to resolve the Kavanaugh hearings between now and Election Day or certainly the Senate is looking to do that. But beyond that, I think it's mostly noise.

LACQUA: Chris, thank you, Chris Marangi there of Gabelli funds, he stays with us.

(BREAK)

FU: For Russia, it's sanctions, for Turkey obviously is what happens with monetary policy. Chris Marangi here with us from Gabelli, for Argentina it's what happens with the IMF. When we look at emerging markets, it seems like investors have been pretty careful about making sure they don't lump Turkey and Argentina with the rest of the EM's. For a country like China, where does it fit in? Is China even an E.M. at this point?

MARANGI: Yes, I wouldn't consider it an E.M. Certainly, you know, given their size and their geopolitical influence, it creates its own weather. I mean, it is -- it has its own dynamic. It's certainly much different than Turkey and South Africa and Argentina as you mentioned. So, it's sort of its own thing. The financial sector is not as developed as the west and the rule of laws not as strong as in the west. It's not quite emerged yet, but it's its own asset class.

FU: And of course there's also the issue with the economy slowing down. Do you not invest in companies that have exposure to China because of that, or because for instance U.S. -- the trade war issues is going to impact those companies?

MARANGI: It's certainly a factor. One of our themes is make it here, sell it there. So, one of our larger areas of investment historically has been in the aerospace sector. China is a big customer -- going to be the biggest customer for those companies. So -- but that is a favorite sector somewhat exempt from the tariff issue. But we look companies in China like Tencent which has some of its dynamics, industries that we like and we know that happened to be based in China and have Chinas then in market.

(BREAK)

FU: Let's bring Chris Marangi, co-CIO of Gabelli Funds here with me. And, of course, we've been looking very carefully at this. You look at mediate companies overall. When you look at Facebook, when you look at Twitter and they commit to focusing more on cleaning up everything, does that mean more resources spent on profiling, on monitoring. I mean, for Facebook, they have the cash to do that but for company like Twitter, that's not really something to have a lot of.

MARANGI: Well, the short answer is yes. I mean, putting this in historical context, 1930s you had radio regulated, post-World War II we had television regulated prohibition and owning a newspaper and a broadcast station to say market limit to a national reach equal time, all these things put in place to limit the voice of any particular station owner.

For us today, we have not caught up with the dominant media which is internet, which is social media. And so there's going to be some kind of regulation, I don't know what form that takes, probably enhancement in privacy and enhancement in transparency requirements, but that's going to cost money clearly.

We saw some indication of that in the second quarter results for Facebook when they basically tried to get ahead of this and they're going to spend more money, so that's a short term headwind to earnings growth but long term as you point it out it probably entrenches the large pipelines because they're the ones who have the scale to basically put this things (ph) in place.

LACQUA: All right, what's the -- Chris, it's difficult at the moment as you say to see what kind of regulation they would face. But what's the worse kind of regulation that could be imposed on them. And do you really see a lot of these companies being proactive and trying to put something in place that feels better to the consumer before they get flopped with more regulation?

MARANGI: Yes, clearly they are doing that, although interestingly Google did not show at that hearing and they have been targeted specifically by the President for other reasons. But, you know, again, in terms of what's the worse kind of regulation, there have been a number of ideas. One has been to actually make social media companies or all internet companies liable for the content that appears on their sites, so you're bringing the legal system in a kind of unknown costs associated with that into the equation and I don't know if that happens or not.

The tech companies don't have a lot of friends on the Republican side of the aisle at the moment which historically or they could really are -- had favored Democrats historically. We'll see what happens if there's a change in Congress.

LACQUA: All right, Chris, thank you so much Chris Marangi there of Gabelli Funds.

(BREAK)

FU: It is now time for single best chart and we are joined of course once again by Chris Marangi, Gabelli Funds co-CIO. And Chris, I pulled up this chart here that shows Citigroup's news implied sentiment indicator which is another way of tracking sentiment on U.S. stocks. And the bars here show, the red bars in particular that there's a lot more bearishness in equities about equities, at least as cited by Bloomberg news stories, while the S&P 500 in white continues moves higher.

Citigroup's not the only one that's been sounding the alarm over recent gains in the U.S. stocks. Goldman Sachs do the same, Stifel Nicolaus also made a point out of the Fed raises rates two more times, it could trigger an equity bear market. What do you make of all of this? What do you make of this that people are now piling in on this idea that we're at a tipping point?

MARANGI: Yes, the most hated bull market in history, the lowest bull market in history and we're the second-largest economic expansion on record. And I don't see any reason that won't be the longest. We need to make it to June of 2019 to be the longest and from the bottom up perspective, you know, industrial demand still reasonably strong, consumers in good shape.

You know, we've talked for years and years about green shoots as signs of recovery. Now we're going to talk a little bit about brown leaves and some of the things that could tip us into recession and end this bull market. And those are things like labor market tightening, higher import costs, steel, oil, freight. We're seeing some of that but nothing that worries me too much at the moment.

FU: So if you're putting new money to work right now, where would you put it in the U.S. market? And you probably don't want to go into big tech which you've seen in the line sure of the gains in U.S. stocks overall. Where do you go now for that turning point?

MARANGI: Yes, I mean, look, so I think we're bottom up investors. We're not allocating by sector, we're looking company by company and there's still companies within tech, a category which is going to change this month by the way where there's value. We're still finding some bargains.

You know, I think in general the level of marginal safety of the market is narrow certainly than it's been in a couple of years, but M&A is still strong. You're still seeing some strength in some of the industrial companies and there are certain sectors that have to left behind to a degree like for example banking and some of the consumer staples names and even some media names which have been out of favor. Yes.

LACQUA: Chris, we're late cycle in the U.S. at the same time, these tax cuts will come to an end. What is the likelihood of recession in the U.S. in the next 18 months?

MARANGI: Well, we're certainly going to have another recession in the U.S., again, the question is what's the timing. Again, I don't see anything today from a bottom up perspective which would lead me to believe that it's going to be in the next 18 months, but it will come and --

LACQUA: Not even a trade war?

MARANGI: Well, certainly the trade war and the political situation spinning out of control are sort of the wildcards. But, you know, I think this expansion in the old-fashioned way with the cycle of rate tightening which, you know, we seem to be on track for.

FU: Well, the Fed do -- I'm sorry, go ahead Francine.

LACQUA: Thanks Scarlet, will the Fed do everything it can not to invert the yield curve?

MARANGI: I'm not sure if that's totally within their power. They face a lot of external forces which are flattening the yield curve. And, you know, obviously everybody talks about the predictive power of the yield curve, but it's not necessary positive so -- but certainly the Fed is aware of that.

FU: Francine, I'm sorry for jumping in on you. I'm just so excited to ask Chris. What are you doing then with your funds? How are you positioning yourself right now?

MARANGI: Well, we're -- we try to be more or less fully invested and we are at the moment. We're looking for good companies trading and discuss to their private market or intrinsic value where something we think ago right for the moment next two years to three years whether it's a change in a regulation, a change in management, and maybe industry consolidation. So we're certainly seeing lots of various of consolidation media among them as well as some of the consumer names. So, again, we're finding ideas.

FU: What's the one thing that you think you can do or won't do once we get the midterm elections out of the way.

MARANGI: Well, I think we're more or less ignoring the midterm elections in terms of the way we're positioning the portfolios. You know, interestingly I think post the midterms we'll start to focus on 2020 and we'll see what candidates are getting traction in Iowa and, you know, the market will notice if somebody like a Senator Warren or Senator Sanders looks to be the nominee and we'll obviously we'll look and see if somebody's going to challenge Trump on the Republican side.

LACQUA: All right, Chris, thank you so much. It's been fun to come back Chris Marangi there of Gabelli Funds.

(BREAK)

END

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let's ask someone else. Chris Marangi, Gabelli Funds co-chief investment officer, joining us here in our 11.30 studios.

Chris, should we care about this?

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, GABELLI FUNDS: Well, yesterday was a real three-ring circus in Washington between the Kavanaugh hearings, the op-ed and these hearings.

ABRAMOWICZ: A normal day.

MARANGI: A normal day. And this comes on the context of course of Trump going after Google on Twitter and Bernie Sanders introducing the Stop BEZOS Act. So big tech is a, one could say, under siege.

ABRAMOWICZ: But it has been for a while.

MARANGI: It has been.

ABRAMOWICZ: I mean is there anything that kind of came out yesterday that really --

MARANGI: No, I don't think so.

ABRAMOWICZ: OK.

MARANGI: And I think the fact that Google didn't show up and had a little placard on their empty chair was indicative of what they think of these hearings. But I think ultimately, listen, radio was regulated this medium in 1934 --

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes.

MARANGI: -- over the post-World War II era, lots of regulations in place to limit the voice of any particular broadcast television network owner. And we're just catching up now in the internet age.

And so there will be more regulation, more requirements on the part of the internet companies and that's going to have a cause associated with it.

FERRO: Why don't we celebrate in the company as successful as Amazon in this country? Why don't politicians celebrating this? This is a huge success story, the envy of most of the world.

MARANGI: It is, but it's a big company with a lot of influence and those companies tend to be targeted by politicians. So, interestingly, obviously, that it comes from the left and, you know --

ABRAMOWICZ: And the right.

MARANGI: And the right, which is what's makes it interesting.

ABRAMOWICZ: Well, you know, you mentioned Google, you mentioned that little placard and how they felt about the hearings. Google shares were actually down really a percent ahead of the open today.

MARANGI: Yes.

ABRAMOWICZ: Facebook and Twitter were actually flat. Do you think that that's significant or is it just sort of noise?

MARANGI: I think that's noise at this point. You know, currently, Google survived the privacy regulation regime in Europe pretty well. And I think the end game here is that the companies with scale like Google and Facebook and even Twitter are going to be the ones who were best able to put into systems to comply with whatever Washington wants. And they're going to be further entrenched by regulation.

FERRO: Chris, you help run Gabelli Funds, that's a lot of money. When you look at the tech sector right now, is there any reason why you wouldn't allocate capital to that sector based on a risk of regulation somewhere somehow in the future?

MARANGI: Well, listen, you know, I think it is just one element of the things that we look at. You know, we invest -- we've invested for many, many years, decades in the cable sector. And the biggest risk for the cable sector, the distribution industry has been always will be regulation. And that's just something that you have to digest and see if it's accounted for in the multiples.

ABRAMOWICZ: So right now, given the fact that you have a lot of big analysts saying things look a little hetty (ph) (INAUDIBLE) off the table, what's the biggest opportunity that you see right now?

MARANGI: Yes. So, listen, you know, the extended FANG, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, Microsoft and Apple, are collectively 4.4 trillion, it's like 15% of the S&P, they've accounted for about half of the gains in the S&P so far this year.

You know, those companies I think in aggregate are probably a little bit ahead of themselves. Among them, there are probably better buys like, in my view, Google than say Amazon.

But, you know, beyond that, we have other areas that we look at. We like the cable sector. We think there's going to be consolidation amongst broadcast television networks. That's an interesting area amongst others.

FERRO: Chris Marangi, great to catch up with you today.

MARANGI: Thank you.

FERRO: Thanks for dropping by in the studio. Gabelli Funds co-CIO.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5T6X-RXH1-JBHT-D1RK-00000-00Chris Marangi is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisChris Marangi is interviewed on BB SurveillanceWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let's ask someone else. Chris Marangi, Gabelli Funds co-chief investment officer, joining us here in our 11.30 studios.

Chris, should we care about this?

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, GABELLI FUNDS: Well, yesterday was a real three-ring circus in Washington between the Kavanaugh hearings, the op-ed and these hearings.

ABRAMOWICZ: A normal day.

MARANGI: A normal day. And this comes on the context of course of Trump going after Google on Twitter and Bernie Sanders introducing the Stop BEZOS Act. So big tech is a, one could say, under siege.

ABRAMOWICZ: But it has been for a while.

MARANGI: It has been.

ABRAMOWICZ: I mean is there anything that kind of came out yesterday that really --

MARANGI: No, I don't think so.

ABRAMOWICZ: OK.

MARANGI: And I think the fact that Google didn't show up and had a little placard on their empty chair was indicative of what they think of these hearings. But I think ultimately, listen, radio was regulated this medium in 1934 --

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes.

MARANGI: -- over the post-World War II era, lots of regulations in place to limit the voice of any particular broadcast television network owner. And we're just catching up now in the internet age.

And so there will be more regulation, more requirements on the part of the internet companies and that's going to have a cause associated with it.

FERRO: Why don't we celebrate in the company as successful as Amazon in this country? Why don't politicians celebrating this? This is a huge success story, the envy of most of the world.

MARANGI: It is, but it's a big company with a lot of influence and those companies tend to be targeted by politicians. So, interestingly, obviously, that it comes from the left and, you know --

ABRAMOWICZ: And the right.

MARANGI: And the right, which is what's makes it interesting.

ABRAMOWICZ: Well, you know, you mentioned Google, you mentioned that little placard and how they felt about the hearings. Google shares were actually down really a percent ahead of the open today.

MARANGI: Yes.

ABRAMOWICZ: Facebook and Twitter were actually flat. Do you think that that's significant or is it just sort of noise?

MARANGI: I think that's noise at this point. You know, currently, Google survived the privacy regulation regime in Europe pretty well. And I think the end game here is that the companies with scale like Google and Facebook and even Twitter are going to be the ones who were best able to put into systems to comply with whatever Washington wants. And they're going to be further entrenched by regulation.

FERRO: Chris, you help run Gabelli Funds, that's a lot of money. When you look at the tech sector right now, is there any reason why you wouldn't allocate capital to that sector based on a risk of regulation somewhere somehow in the future?

MARANGI: Well, listen, you know, I think it is just one element of the things that we look at. You know, we invest -- we've invested for many, many years, decades in the cable sector. And the biggest risk for the cable sector, the distribution industry has been always will be regulation. And that's just something that you have to digest and see if it's accounted for in the multiples.

ABRAMOWICZ: So right now, given the fact that you have a lot of big analysts saying things look a little hetty (ph) (INAUDIBLE) off the table, what's the biggest opportunity that you see right now?

MARANGI: Yes. So, listen, you know, the extended FANG, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, Microsoft and Apple, are collectively 4.4 trillion, it's like 15% of the S&P, they've accounted for about half of the gains in the S&P so far this year.

You know, those companies I think in aggregate are probably a little bit ahead of themselves. Among them, there are probably better buys like, in my view, Google than say Amazon.

But, you know, beyond that, we have other areas that we look at. We like the cable sector. We think there's going to be consolidation amongst broadcast television networks. That's an interesting area amongst others.

FERRO: Chris Marangi, great to catch up with you today.

MARANGI: Thank you.

FERRO: Thanks for dropping by in the studio. Gabelli Funds co-CIO.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5SXN-4M51-JB20-G0P4-00000-00Chris Marangi is interviewed on BB Surveillance.2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE7:00 AM ESTChris MarangiNEWSInternational073080cb.556Chris Marangi is interviewed on BB Surveillance.Tom Keene

Chris Marangi, Jonathan Ferro

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS, INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLACNE

JULY 30, 2018

SPEAKERS: CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: To the media update, we're thrilled that Chris Marangi is with us with Gabelli, as we look at media. And of course, Chris, to explain this with a value investment proposition of Mario Gabelli and your team, you've always been in media. How much of a value is Cable TV after the Fox, Disney, Comcast soap opera?

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS: Good morning, Tom and Jonathan, great to be here. Yes, the Cable companies Comcast, Charter, amongst others are a bargain today, more of a bargain than they were before, let's say, a counter bit for Fox. These are good catch willing entities (ph) recurring cash or the recurring cash flow to shareholders and that's why we like them.

KEENE: Comcast did that shift from huge build out to use of cash. On the Bloomberg, their five-year dividend growth as a lofty 4.22 percent. I'm assuming they can sustain that, but can they actually deliver double-digit dividend growth as the cash flow that persistent?

MARANGI: Yes. The return on capital in the cash flow are growing substantially as the business make shifts from video where they're giving up 60 cents in every dollar to the content companies to broadband where they're keeping that money. And have a lot of pricing power (ph).

KEENE: What's interesting here folks, as we were talking with Craig Moffett in MoffettNathanson with us, really important work on Comcast recent than Marangi is sort of on what's called the buy side which is he's actually making portfolio decisions in acquiring shares as well. If Comcast and Cable is cheap, what's rich in media?

MARANGI: Well you point statistically to the same stocks obviously and there's been sort of saying anti-thing (ph) trade when the (INAUDIBLE) are strong. Some of the traditional media companies tend to be weak. I think that's starting to breakdown a little bit. But, you know, it doesn't mean that Google and Netflix and others don't have outstanding businesses. Netflix, in particularly just, you know, appears to trade at a -- with a minimal margin of safety.

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes. It thought it was interesting last week, Chris, that the outperformance came from the old economy equities and the underperformance came from the technology stocks. And I just wonder whether that's one off weak or whether we're starting to a transitions where worldwide can build some confidence around what's happening in the global economy as Europe prepares to have stabilized China that appears to be shifting towards the easing then we have that great growth here in the United States in a second quarter.

MARANGI: Yes, I think that's an interesting point, Jonathan. I think the big tech names were viewed as safe havens in some ways as growth elsewhere starting this. So, you know, I think as we see a little bit of stabilization, the trend to value should persist.

FERRO: Chris, the trend to value has been a right difficult one to buy into --

MARANGI: It's been a long time.

FERRO: -- over the last year. And many of our listeners have heard that again and again and again over the last couple of years. Why is it different this time?

MARANGI: Well we're hoping it's different this time. And, you know, in the end, we think that value will always went out. And, you know, kind of a -- the good place is to be with maybe a choppy (INAUDIBLE) environment but a stable economic environment.

FERRO: Does that leave financials, Chris?

MARANGI: It should. You know, every time we watch the curve and what's happening with the funding in the curve, I think that's been a little bit of an issue but, yes, the financials again statistically look for a two- pair.

FERRO: It's something that's dominated psychology, is it dominated profitability? And I'm talking about the yield curve here, Chris. Has it dominated profitability because I didn't see it, will it?

MARANGI: No, I think, you know, the banks are able to make money if they're in a better regulatory situation than they have been a long time. They'll return a lot more capital to shareholders. So, you know, I think maybe we're overly focused on the shape of the curve.

KEENE: OK, we're overly focused on the shape of the curve, but it's determinant to some extend forward. What about the shape of nominal GDP? I mean, if this is -- if this GDP is good as it gets in an abs (ph) way, what abs (ph) in the Chris Marangi world, the revenues ab?

MARANGI: Yes. So, you know, we've been talking about actually margins for years. And, you know, margins just continue to go up as if we continue to defined companies -- continue to define ways to save money. Obviously, where they seem from earnings, the first two weeks has been increased cost, ample (ph) cost, steel, energy, labor freight (ph). And so we're starting to see some of those sciences inflation which may impact margins. But, you know, we could get into another gear where we see an increase in productivity again.

FERRO: Well Chris, at this conversation with Jeff Rosenberg of BlackRock on Friday and we kept asking this question, is this good as it gets and it may will be the highest rate of growth for any given quarter for this administration. But I think a bigger question, and this is something that Jeff was pushing ever at BlackRock, is whether we've broken out into a higher trend growth, the way from low twos (ph) and something close to the three. Do you have the confidence that we've done that, Chris?

MARANGI: You know, we're bottom up guys and we look at individual companies and we have companies that we listen to on these earnings costs and, you know, they see, for the most part, pretty clear skies ahead. You know, absence some of these ample (ph) cost and absence some of the risk of trade wars. But the consumer seems to be in good shape. Housing is OK and, you know, globally, you know, seeing some pick up.

FERRO: It's funny that we've just had a quarter of not 4 percent and I've heard so many people talking about where do we get our recession at some point back in the next year or early 2020. I've heard a lot of people discussed trade wars and then Carapello (ph) come out this morning raises fuller (ph) guidance. Fuller (ph) guidance raise in the quarter that was dominated by discussions about trade wars and tariffs. How do you reconcile these two things, Chris?

MARANGI: Well, you know, make farmers great again, I guess is the hat that I saw. And, you know, that certainly helps somebody agricultural companies. And, you know, the global demand is there.

KEENE: Jon, I think that's a really important insight.

MARANGI: Great to catch up with you, Chris, of Gabelli Funds, Co-Chief Investment Officer.

(BREAK)

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

[*] TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: To the media update, we're thrilled that Chris Marangi is with us with Gabelli, as we look at media. CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS: Good morning, Tom and Jonathan, great to be here. These are good catch willing entities (ph) recurring cash or the recurring cash flow to shareholders and that's why we like them.

KEENE: Comcast did that shift from huge build out to use of cash. On the Bloomberg, their five-year dividend growth as a lofty 4.22 percent. I'm assuming they can sustain that, but can they actually deliver double-digit dividend growth as the cash flow that persistent?

MARANGI: Yes. The return on capital in the cash flow are growing substantially as the business make shifts from video where they're giving up 60 cents in every dollar to the content companies to broadband where they're keeping that money. And have a lot of pricing power (ph).

KEENE: What's interesting here folks, as we were talking with Craig Moffett in MoffettNathanson with us, really important work on Comcast recent than Marangi is sort of on what's called the buy side which is he's actually making portfolio decisions in acquiring shares as well. If Comcast and Cable is cheap, what's rich in media?

MARANGI: Well you point statistically to the same stocks obviously and there's been sort of saying anti-thing (ph) trade when the (INAUDIBLE) are strong. Some of the traditional media companies tend to be weak. I think that's starting to breakdown a little bit. But, you know, it doesn't mean that Google and Netflix and others don't have outstanding businesses. Netflix, in particularly just, you know, appears to trade at a -- with a minimal margin of safety.

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes. It thought it was interesting last week, Chris, that the outperformance came from the old economy equities and the underperformance came from the technology stocks. MARANGI: Yes, I think that's an interesting point, Jonathan. I think the big tech names were viewed as safe havens in some ways as growth elsewhere starting this. So, you know, I think as we see a little bit of stabilization, the trend to value should persist.

FERRO: Chris, the trend to value has been a right difficult one to buy into --

MARANGI: It's been a long time.

FERRO: -- over the last year. And many of our listeners have heard that again and again and again over the last couple of years. Why is it different this time?

MARANGI: Well we're hoping it's different this time. And, you know, in the end, we think that value will always went out. And, you know, kind of a -- the good place is to be with maybe a choppy (INAUDIBLE) environment but a stable economic environment.

FERRO: Does that leave financials, Chris?

MARANGI: It should. You know, every time we watch the curve and what's happening with the funding in the curve, I think that's been a little bit of an issue but, yes, the financials again statistically look for a two- pair.

FERRO: It's something that's dominated psychology, is it dominated profitability? And I'm talking about the yield curve here, Chris. Has it dominated profitability because I didn't see it, will it?

MARANGI: No, I think, you know, the banks are able to make money if they're in a better regulatory situation than they have been a long time. They'll return a lot more capital to shareholders. So, you know, I think maybe we're overly focused on the shape of the curve.

KEENE: OK, we're overly focused on the shape of the curve, but it's determinant to some extend forward. What about the shape of nominal GDP? I mean, if this is -- if this GDP is good as it gets in an abs (ph) way, what abs (ph) in the Chris Marangi world, the revenues ab?

MARANGI: Yes. So, you know, we've been talking about actually margins for years. And, you know, margins just continue to go up as if we continue to defined companies -- continue to define ways to save money. Obviously, where they seem from earnings, the first two weeks has been increased cost, ample (ph) cost, steel, energy, labor freight (ph). And so we're starting to see some of those sciences inflation which may impact margins. But, you know, we could get into another gear where we see an increase in productivity again.

FERRO: Well Chris, at this conversation with Jeff Rosenberg of BlackRock on Friday and we kept asking this question, is this good as it gets and it may will be the highest rate of growth for any given quarter for this administration. But I think a bigger question, and this is something that Jeff was pushing ever at BlackRock, is whether we've broken out into a higher trend growth, the way from low twos (ph) and something close to the three. Do you have the confidence that we've done that, Chris?

MARANGI: You know, we're bottom up guys and we look at individual companies and we have companies that we listen to on these earnings costs and, you know, they see, for the most part, pretty clear skies ahead. You know, absence some of these ample (ph) cost and absence some of the risk of trade wars. But the consumer seems to be in good shape. Housing is OK and, you know, globally, you know, seeing some pick up.

FERRO: It's funny that we've just had a quarter of not 4 percent and I've heard so many people talking about where do we get our recession at some point back in the next year or early 2020. I've heard a lot of people discussed trade wars and then Carapello (ph) come out this morning raises fuller (ph) guidance. Fuller (ph) guidance raise in the quarter that was dominated by discussions about trade wars and tariffs. How do you reconcile these two things, Chris?

MARANGI: Well, you know, make farmers great again, I guess is the hat that I saw. And, you know, that certainly helps somebody agricultural companies. And, you know, the global demand is there.

KEENE: Jon, I think that's a really important insight.

MARANGI: Great to catch up with you, Chris, of Gabelli Funds, Co-Chief Investment Officer.

[*]

urn:contentItem:5T6X-RXM1-JBHT-D32Y-00000-00Chris Marangi is interviewed on BB TV2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisChris Marangi is interviewed on BB TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Now, joining us here in New York is Chris Marangi, he is Gabelli Funds Co-CIO. And Chris, we were just talking about what's happening in Washington and how that's eating up all of the attention, sucking up all the oxygen there. As an investor, we know that when the president tend to get cornered, and it's not just this president, any president, they tend to look for something else, they look for distractions, they look for something to focus their energy on. Do you expect or anticipate unexpected headlines on trade on North Korea that could come out and change the scope of where we are headed?

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS: Well, administration in turmoil is probably a headline you could've applied in any point in the last 18 months. And what we're focused on is two months from now. Today is September 6, November 6 of the elections in the U.S. So a lot of this is noise, it will focus on the election and I think the expectation at this point is that the Democrats will at least take the House, the Senate is up for grabs and historically divided government has been good for the markets. And so whether it's people inside the administration or other branches of government modulating the impulses of the executive, that's generally viewed positively by the market.

FU: So as an investor, do you look for people within the administration and indeed the President himself to make the decisions that would be good for markets, for the business environment leading up to the midterms because that's where they want to keep the focus on a strong economy?

MARANGI: Yes, that would be smart of the president. I think -- but I think the president will between now and Election Day probably appeal to his base and, yes, I would expect some headlines about trade and immigrations. Somebody -- but on issues on that election.

FU: But resolutions on those?

MARANGI: I doubt that anything gets resolved. We have of course also the --

FU: Right, thanks so much --

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Go ahead Chris.

MARANGI: Yes, obviously -- you know, obviously there are other things going on in Washington was a bit of a three ring circus yesterday between the Kavanaugh hearing and the social media hearings.

So, you know, obviously we'll look to resolve the Kavanaugh hearings between now and Election Day or certainly the Senate is looking to do that. But beyond that, I think it's mostly noise.

LACQUA: Chris, thank you, Chris Marangi there of Gabelli funds, he stays with us.

(BREAK)

FU: For Russia, it's sanctions, for Turkey obviously is what happens with monetary policy. Chris Marangi here with us from Gabelli, for Argentina it's what happens with the IMF. When we look at emerging markets, it seems like investors have been pretty careful about making sure they don't lump Turkey and Argentina with the rest of the EM's. For a country like China, where does it fit in? Is China even an E.M. at this point?

MARANGI: Yes, I wouldn't consider it an E.M. Certainly, you know, given their size and their geopolitical influence, it creates its own weather. I mean, it is -- it has its own dynamic. It's certainly much different than Turkey and South Africa and Argentina as you mentioned. So, it's sort of its own thing. The financial sector is not as developed as the west and the rule of laws not as strong as in the west. It's not quite emerged yet, but it's its own asset class.

FU: And of course there's also the issue with the economy slowing down. Do you not invest in companies that have exposure to China because of that, or because for instance U.S. -- the trade war issues is going to impact those companies?

MARANGI: It's certainly a factor. One of our themes is make it here, sell it there. So, one of our larger areas of investment historically has been in the aerospace sector. China is a big customer -- going to be the biggest customer for those companies. So -- but that is a favorite sector somewhat exempt from the tariff issue. But we look companies in China like Tencent which has some of its dynamics, industries that we like and we know that happened to be based in China and have Chinas then in market.

(BREAK)

FU: Let's bring Chris Marangi, co-CIO of Gabelli Funds here with me. And, of course, we've been looking very carefully at this. You look at mediate companies overall. When you look at Facebook, when you look at Twitter and they commit to focusing more on cleaning up everything, does that mean more resources spent on profiling, on monitoring. I mean, for Facebook, they have the cash to do that but for company like Twitter, that's not really something to have a lot of.

MARANGI: Well, the short answer is yes. I mean, putting this in historical context, 1930s you had radio regulated, post-World War II we had television regulated prohibition and owning a newspaper and a broadcast station to say market limit to a national reach equal time, all these things put in place to limit the voice of any particular station owner.

For us today, we have not caught up with the dominant media which is internet, which is social media. And so there's going to be some kind of regulation, I don't know what form that takes, probably enhancement in privacy and enhancement in transparency requirements, but that's going to cost money clearly.

We saw some indication of that in the second quarter results for Facebook when they basically tried to get ahead of this and they're going to spend more money, so that's a short term headwind to earnings growth but long term as you point it out it probably entrenches the large pipelines because they're the ones who have the scale to basically put this things (ph) in place.

LACQUA: All right, what's the -- Chris, it's difficult at the moment as you say to see what kind of regulation they would face. But what's the worse kind of regulation that could be imposed on them. And do you really see a lot of these companies being proactive and trying to put something in place that feels better to the consumer before they get flopped with more regulation?

MARANGI: Yes, clearly they are doing that, although interestingly Google did not show at that hearing and they have been targeted specifically by the President for other reasons. But, you know, again, in terms of what's the worse kind of regulation, there have been a number of ideas. One has been to actually make social media companies or all internet companies liable for the content that appears on their sites, so you're bringing the legal system in a kind of unknown costs associated with that into the equation and I don't know if that happens or not.

The tech companies don't have a lot of friends on the Republican side of the aisle at the moment which historically or they could really are -- had favored Democrats historically. We'll see what happens if there's a change in Congress.

LACQUA: All right, Chris, thank you so much Chris Marangi there of Gabelli Funds.

(BREAK)

FU: It is now time for single best chart and we are joined of course once again by Chris Marangi, Gabelli Funds co-CIO. And Chris, I pulled up this chart here that shows Citigroup's news implied sentiment indicator which is another way of tracking sentiment on U.S. stocks. And the bars here show, the red bars in particular that there's a lot more bearishness in equities about equities, at least as cited by Bloomberg news stories, while the S&P 500 in white continues moves higher.

Citigroup's not the only one that's been sounding the alarm over recent gains in the U.S. stocks. Goldman Sachs do the same, Stifel Nicolaus also made a point out of the Fed raises rates two more times, it could trigger an equity bear market. What do you make of all of this? What do you make of this that people are now piling in on this idea that we're at a tipping point?

MARANGI: Yes, the most hated bull market in history, the lowest bull market in history and we're the second-largest economic expansion on record. And I don't see any reason that won't be the longest. We need to make it to June of 2019 to be the longest and from the bottom up perspective, you know, industrial demand still reasonably strong, consumers in good shape.

You know, we've talked for years and years about green shoots as signs of recovery. Now we're going to talk a little bit about brown leaves and some of the things that could tip us into recession and end this bull market. And those are things like labor market tightening, higher import costs, steel, oil, freight. We're seeing some of that but nothing that worries me too much at the moment.

FU: So if you're putting new money to work right now, where would you put it in the U.S. market? And you probably don't want to go into big tech which you've seen in the line sure of the gains in U.S. stocks overall. Where do you go now for that turning point?

MARANGI: Yes, I mean, look, so I think we're bottom up investors. We're not allocating by sector, we're looking company by company and there's still companies within tech, a category which is going to change this month by the way where there's value. We're still finding some bargains.

You know, I think in general the level of marginal safety of the market is narrow certainly than it's been in a couple of years, but M&A is still strong. You're still seeing some strength in some of the industrial companies and there are certain sectors that have to left behind to a degree like for example banking and some of the consumer staples names and even some media names which have been out of favor. Yes.

LACQUA: Chris, we're late cycle in the U.S. at the same time, these tax cuts will come to an end. What is the likelihood of recession in the U.S. in the next 18 months?

MARANGI: Well, we're certainly going to have another recession in the U.S., again, the question is what's the timing. Again, I don't see anything today from a bottom up perspective which would lead me to believe that it's going to be in the next 18 months, but it will come and --

LACQUA: Not even a trade war?

MARANGI: Well, certainly the trade war and the political situation spinning out of control are sort of the wildcards. But, you know, I think this expansion in the old-fashioned way with the cycle of rate tightening which, you know, we seem to be on track for.

FU: Well, the Fed do -- I'm sorry, go ahead Francine.

LACQUA: Thanks Scarlet, will the Fed do everything it can not to invert the yield curve?

MARANGI: I'm not sure if that's totally within their power. They face a lot of external forces which are flattening the yield curve. And, you know, obviously everybody talks about the predictive power of the yield curve, but it's not necessary positive so -- but certainly the Fed is aware of that.

FU: Francine, I'm sorry for jumping in on you. I'm just so excited to ask Chris. What are you doing then with your funds? How are you positioning yourself right now?

MARANGI: Well, we're -- we try to be more or less fully invested and we are at the moment. We're looking for good companies trading and discuss to their private market or intrinsic value where something we think ago right for the moment next two years to three years whether it's a change in a regulation, a change in management, and maybe industry consolidation. So we're certainly seeing lots of various of consolidation media among them as well as some of the consumer names. So, again, we're finding ideas.

FU: What's the one thing that you think you can do or won't do once we get the midterm elections out of the way.

MARANGI: Well, I think we're more or less ignoring the midterm elections in terms of the way we're positioning the portfolios. You know, interestingly I think post the midterms we'll start to focus on 2020 and we'll see what candidates are getting traction in Iowa and, you know, the market will notice if somebody like a Senator Warren or Senator Sanders looks to be the nominee and we'll obviously we'll look and see if somebody's going to challenge Trump on the Republican side.

LACQUA: All right, Chris, thank you so much. It's been fun to come back Chris Marangi there of Gabelli Funds.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
