urn:contentItem:5XR3-3GY1-DXVP-V552-00000-00Christopher Koopman: Democrats wrong on big-tech solutions2019-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisCOLUMNISTSChristopher Koopman: Democrats wrong on big-tech solutionsStaff Writer

From Elizabeth Warren to Tulsi Gabbard, the Democratic presidential candidates have come out strong for breaking up big tech. It has become a central focus of Warren's campaign, which has caused business leaders like Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg to voice concern, and the fight over big tech within the Democratic Party presidential primaries has bled into the courts.

In all of this, Andrew Yang has emerged as a reasoned voice against breaking up these companies. In a recent op-ed, he noted that "Breaking up Facebook or Apple sounds good, but it wouldn't address this issue." His alternative, however, is not a practical solution either. Instead of breaking tech companies up, Yang proposes a Department of the Attention Economy that will implement regulations that curb what he sees as "the negative effects of smartphones and social media."

Both the history and current reality of the Internet suggest that Yang's proposal has little chance of alleviating the addictive qualities or mental health effects that he says social media and big tech are having on Americans, young people in particular. It might only serve to make things worse.

We don't have to guess what a regulated internet will look like. For most of its history, in fact, the Internet was a tightly controlled platform called the ARPAnet, which served as the academic research network that preceded today's Internet. It was a platform in which norms and behavior were dictated to users by the federal government. Here is an excerpt of MIT's 1982 guide for new users of ARPAnet explained how it should be used:

"It is considered illegal to use the ARPAnet for anything which is not in direct support of Government business. At the Al lab, we use the network to talk to other researchers about all kinds of things. For example, personal messages to other ARPAnet subscribers (for example, to arrange a get-together or check and say a friendly hello) are generally not considered harmful. This is one of the ways in which we adapt the network environment to our community. It is very clear that without that sort of freedom, the network could not have evolved to its current point of technical and social sophistication.

"Sending electronic mail over the ARPAnet for commercial profit or political purposes is both antisocial and illegal. By sending such messages, you can offend many people, and it is possible to get MIT in serious trouble with the Government agencies which manage the ARPAnet."

You see, as a platform tightly controlled by the federal government, ARPAnet was regulated in an effort to stave off the perceived negative or "antisocial" effects of the commercial or political use of the platform. And while some are now arguing today that perhaps those same standards should be reinstated (just look at Twitter's ban of political advertising), it is hard to argue that the ARPAnet as conceived in 1982 would have changed the world in the way that the successive version of the commercial internet has.

But many, including Yang and Republican Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.), argue in favor of heavily and specifically regulating social media in the name of curbing "social media addiction." And while we still have much to learn about whether or not this "addiction" is a serious problem, it ignores why people use the Internet, to begin with. Yang's effort to create a federal agency focused on "curbing design features that maximize screen time" and discourage "Design features that encourage social validation" assumes that people are merely tricked and manipulated into using today's most popular Internet platforms. The data, however, suggests that it is not true at all.

Why do people seem so "addicted" to the Internet? It may be passion, not addiction, driving users. A recent survey of Internet users found that approximately 80 million - 38.15% - of U.S. adults use the Internet to pursue hobbies and passion projects. And out of those 80 million, nearly 35% of them say that the internet is essential to that pursuit. This means that there are just short of 30 million Americans that can only pursue their passion projects with the Internet. Looking back at the limited acceptable applications of the Internet of the early 80s, it is hard to explain why taking us back in time will make millions of Americans better off.

Putting a federal agency in a position to determine acceptable and unacceptable behavior on the internet should not be a thought experiment played out by presidential hopefuls. Instead, we should look at the history of the internet in order to understand more clearly what that world would really be like. And while "big tech" has become the target of frustration and focus of the Democratic primaries, taking us back 30 years will only serve to undermine the greatest platform we have today, to connect millions of Americans with their passions and help them find more meaning in their lives.

urn:contentItem:5RWW-F391-JCMN-Y4PW-00000-00Christopher Wylie, the 28-year-old whistleblower of the Trump-linked data firm Cambridge Analytica, says his Facebook account has been disabled2018-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisChristopher Wylie, the 28-year-old whistleblower of the Trump-linked data firm Cambridge Analytica, says his Facebook account has been disabledDave Smith

Mar 18, 2018( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) YouTube/The Guardian Christopher Wylie is the 28-year-old whistleblower on Cambridge Analytica, the data-analytics firm that played an important role in Trump's 2016 campaign and the Brexit Leave campaign. Wylie said his Facebook account was disabled on Sunday, "for blowing the whistle, on something they have known privately for two years." Facebook says it is suspending Wylie's Facebook account, despite his role as a whistleblower, as it carries out its investigation on Cambridge Analytica.Christopher Wylie, the 28-year-old man who both founded and blew the whistle on Cambridge Analytica, the data-analytics firm that played an important role in Trump's 2016 campaign and the Brexit Leave campaign, had his Facebook account disabled on Sunday.Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/975335430043389952?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw Suspended by @facebook[1]. For blowing the whistle.

On something they have known privately for 2 years. pic.twitter.com/iSu6VwqUdG[2];Facebook suspended Cambridge Analytica from its platform[3] on Friday, amid multiple revealing stories published in The New York Times[4] and The Guardian[5] over the weekend that included interviews with Wylie, who oversaw the conception and realization of Cambridge Analytica's tool that harvested millions of Facebook profiles illegitimately, to be used for various political campaigns in both the US and UK. In an interview published in The Guardian[6] on Sunday, Wylie detailed how Cambridge Analytica harvested data from more than 50 million Facebook profiles between June and August 2014, even sharing a 2016 letter from Facebook's own lawyers admitting that Cambridge Analytica "had acquired the data illegitimately," and asking Wylie to delete the data. Perhaps most troubling is that, according to Wylie, Facebook never followed up in the two years since that letter to see if he had, in fact, deleted the stolen data. (He didn't.)Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/975029336834060288?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw Welp. Tech is definitely about to get regulated. And probably for the best. https://t.co/hvibNfqSRL[7]Despite reportedly having evidence that Cambridge Analytica had illegitimately collected user data, Facebook did not suspend Cambridge Analytica until Friday — more than two years after the alleged data breach from Cambridge Analytica was first reported, and four days after The Guardian reportedly sought comment[8] from Facebook about the story. Facebook, for its part, doesn't call the incident a "breach."[9] A spokesperson told The Guardian: "Protecting people's information is at the heart of everything we do, and we require the same from people who operate apps on Facebook. If these reports are true, it's a serious abuse of our rules." So, why did Facebook suspend Wylie's account? Business Insider reached out for comment, and Facebook was not immediately available to respond. Facebook did say on Friday that it would suspend Wylie's account — as well as the accounts of Dr. Aleksandr Kogan, a psychology professor at the University of Cambridge, and Strategic Communication Laboratories, Cambridge Analytica's parent company — while it carried out its investigation. It's unclear if Wylie's account would be restored after the investigation ends. The full stories about Wylie, Cambridge Analytica, Facebook, and the roles they played in the 2016 presidential election are truly incredible and worth reading — The New York Times story[10], as well as The Guardian's interview with Wylie[11] and its story on the harvested Facebook profiles[12]. That was in gang of eight, agreed to in the so-called "border surge." So there's a chance that while the wall might be part of a DACA deal, there could be something that could be spun as or framed as a wall or a physical barrier.

WALLACE: And how do you think -- I mean it's crazy to ask you what's the base going to do, but I'm going to ask you, what do you think the reaction of the real Trump hardliners, the real base will be if they get a deal on DACA that includes citizenship and doesn't include a wall as it had been commonly thought to exist? BENSON: Well, last week I had a long car ride, so I listen to talk radio for about six hours straight, and it was really interesting. They opened the phone lines and it was Trump base voters calling in. And there was some trepidation, there was some concern about where this might go. But, overall, there was a sense that they trust President Trump, that they think that he's three steps ahead of anyone else and that ultimately he's got their interests at heart. And that was sort of reflected across-the-board for most of his supporters. So that's what I would guess would be the case, unless it is egregiously bad.

WALLACE: Rachael, from your post covering Capitol Hill, what do you think is the -- are the prospects for a deal that can be passed on DACA and the prospects for a deal on tax reform?

RACHAEL BADE, POLITICO: You talk to Republicans right now, they would tell you, a slim chance in terms of the White House striking a deal with Democrats and getting it over the line, while cutting out GOP leadership. You know, you mentioned that a lot of the base still has faith in Trump and they see this. They say he knows our interests, he's going to do what is best for us.

There's a totally different feeling on Capitol Hill with GOP leadership. I heard a lot of frustration and questioning of, what is this strategy? What is the end game here? Basically, you know, Republicans control both houses of Congress. You know, so cutting out leadership is not the smartest thing for the president at this point in time, at least Republicans will tell you that.

For instance, take the DACA deal. I was talking to some folks in leadership who were saying that they don't understand why he took the wall off the table to begin with. It's the number one bargaining chip, they said, in terms of negotiating a deal. If you're going to take it off the table with Democrats, you should get something for it. So they're going to try to push him to put that back on the table and sort of use that to get a deal that is possible that conservatives could vote for it.

WALLACE: And what about tax reform? This is -- I pointed out with the two senators, they're so different on tax cuts that would benefit the wealthy, on whether or not it's going to add to the deficit or not, unless you put in what they called dynamic scoring and include a lot of the growth that is a guess whether or not it's going to happen.

BADE: Yes, I don't mean to sound alarmist, but tax reform is also in trouble right now. And it -- again, it goes back to this sort of shift we're seeing in the president going from just working to Republicans, to now wanting to work with Democrats. For instance, Republicans on The Hill, Speaker Paul Ryan, Mitch McConnell, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, Gary Cohn, they've all been writing a Republican bill and they're about to unveil it.

Last week we saw the president come out and float the idea of increasing taxes on the wealthy, which blows in the face of sly-side economics and goes against -- 100 percent against what Republicans would want to see in a tax bill. So there's a fear that he's overstepping right now in terms of reaching out to Democrats and they're concerned that this is going to undercut them. And not only a Republican base, but the president and what he wants to do.

WALLACE: A quick reactions, speaker?

GINGRICH: I think the most interesting side story was Democrats won this big agreement. Everything was going to end in December. The Democrats are going to have this huge leverage because the debt ceiling ended in December. A few days later, Mitch McConnell pointed out that as the majority leader he controlled the paper. And they took out the provisions Schumer most wanted. And --

WALLACE: Which was about extraordinary measures, which means that they can keep the debt ceiling going till March.

GINGRICH: February or March. And he said, you know, I happen to be the majority leader and I control the paper and we did it on my way (ph). And Schumer, faced with that reality, couldn't break -- he couldn't say no. So we're a long way -- this dance is going to continue for a while. I think the Democrats face the real risk. Do they really hate the wall more than they love the dreamers? Because if I were the president, that's the way I'd drive it. I'd say these people are so ideological they'd rather sacrifice the dreamers.

WALLACE: All right. Gridlock breaking out here in Washington.

All right, panel, we have to take a break here.

When we combat, with growing tension between Washington and Silicon Valley, powerful Internet companies face talk of more government oversight. We'll bring back the panel to discuss Congress' new scrutiny of big tech.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK WARNER (D), VIRGINIA SENATOR: I think that we're still at the tip of the iceberg. The fact is, I don't think FaceBook has put the resources, the time. My understanding is they didn't even go back and check all those accounts to see if they had put out -- put out other ads.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: Democratic Senator Mark Warner of Virginia after FaceBook admitted it sold $150,000 worth of ads in the 2016 election to groups linked to Russia, spurring investigations by both congressional committees and Special Counsel Robert Mueller.

And we're back now with the panel.

Speaker Gingrich, how big a development is this and are we beginning to see the end of Washington's hands-off approach to big tech and especially these huge Internet companies? GINGRICH: Yes, look, I think this is probably four to six years behind the curve. These companies are so big, they control so much of our lives, they can set so many different policies internally with no supervision, that having not just the Russian angle, but really looking at the underlying nature of these companies, what they do, how they make decisions, these are the equivalent of gigantic public utilities. And in the information age, they have enormous power. And I don't think you, in a free society, you can't have power that's hidden away in secret, controlled by a handful of billionaires.

WALLACE: Well, one of the things that Mark Warner, who was a tech guy himself before he went into politics, said, that it's the wild, wild west there. Now, some people would say that's one of the reasons it succeed. Are you saying put government clamps on it?

GINGRICH: No, look, I think having the wild, wild west when companies are small is exactly right. Several of these companies are so enormous that there's some sense of, what does it mean to us as a free society to have global corporations run by founding billionaires who are -- have been, in effect, totally out of control and who internally can wipe out a company and wipe -- I mean they can be anti- conservative, they can be anti-liberal, they can do all sorts of things, and there's been almost no supervision, just to surface (ph) the information.

WALLACE: President -- Rachael, President Obama and Democrats, I think you'd agree, generally had a pretty cozy relationship with the big Internet companies, like FaceBook, like Google, like Amazon. Is that changing on Capitol Hill now, as the speaker suggested it should, and is there a partisan divide in how Republicans and Democrats see these Internet behemoths?

BADE: Yes, absolutely. The days of the industry sort of basking in the sunless praise from Washington are basically coming to an end right now. Look, for a long time Congress had sort of a light touch with the tech industry, but now you have Democrats who are furious about these Russia-linked ads that ran in 2016. Republicans are worried that Google is oppressing conservative voices. Both sides are concerned about people's private information being gathered and what happens if they're hacked. And so those are all concerns.

So, yes, generally, Republicans control everything right now in Washington and they're typically anti-regulation. But it's safe to say that this sort of darling industry is now becoming a target as much as anything else.

WALLACE: And do you have any thought about how you do it when the rubber hits the road? How do you allow these companies to grow and prosper but with some guardrails?

BADE: I think that's the question that The Hill is sort of grappling with right now, how do they do this but allow an industry to continue to grow, that influences everyone's life so much? Look, there's a test case that's going on right now on Capitol Hill. There's going to be some hearings coming up in the Senate this week to examine whether big websites and tech companies can be held liable for child sex trafficking on the Internet. Right now they cannot be sued if a user were to put illicit content on the Internet.

So the Senate is going to look at re-examining this. The tech industry is putting a lot of money in K Street to lobby against this. But I think this is an interesting first test, right? Like if -- if they can't -- if they're not going to see something as heinous as child sex trafficking as a reason to regulate, then it's safe to say that big tech still has a lot of power.

WALLACE: It's funny you talk about K Street. It is amazing. Which is the big center of lobbying here in Washington. And there was a chart in "The Wall Street Journal" that show the lobbying expenditures by these companies has just skyrocketed in the last few years.

Julie, where are President Trump and his administration on this? You talk about utilities, Speaker Gingrich. Steve Bannon used to talk about treating FaceBook and Google as public utilities, which meant heavy regulation.

PACE: Right. Steve Bannon, of course, now outside the White House. So, look, the -- at least rhetorically the position of this White House, when it comes to big tech, is so different from the Obama administration, which really wrapped its arms around the Googles and Amazon's and FaceBooks and presented them as examples of American companies that are -- that are growing strong and are dominating on the global stage.

Trump, I think, has been turned off a bit by the fact that some of the leaders of these companies are not particularly pleased with his administration and have spoken out on a lot of issues. I don't think you can divorce this conversation when it comes to the White House from that. But he's also taken on Amazon, and not just for Jeff Bezos's role in owning "The Washington Post," he's taken on Amazon on his Twitter account.

I think that you are seeing some of this stemming from the president's populist message in general as well. I mean he looks at Wall Street and some of the big firms there and I think looks at tech in somewhat of the same way, a massive company that can get out of control. And he -- when he looks at his base, he can see their frustration with that. The frustration of small business owners who see themselves getting taken over by a giant like Amazon.

WALLACE: Yes. There's also this whole question, before I get to you, Guy, about the fact that Internet companies, when they have sales, they don't have to pay taxes, but the mom and pop store in the town on main street does have to pay taxes.

PACE: And that's when you've see him go after Amazon in particular for. He's done this in a -- in a series of tweets. I think it will be interesting to see if this comes up in the discussion on The Hill on tax reform if we are -- do end up talking about a big tax reform package.

WALLACE: That would actually add a lot of revenue, wouldn't it?

PACE: Yes (ph). WALLACE: That would really -- that would get the lobbyists -- because, Guy, there's another aspect of all of this that I want to get to, and that's growing questions about the culture in Silicon Valley.

You had three former female employees of Google just file what they hope will be a class action lawsuit charging them with pay and promotion discrimination. And as you know, there have been a number of complaints and lawsuits alleging sexual harassment in these companies. So that wild, wild west attitude applies also to the culture in Silicon Valley.

BENSON: That's right. So you'll have Democrats, in particular I think, focusing on those problems and equal pay and is there discrimination in Silicon Valley. And then you'll have on the other side, as Rachael alluded to, a lot of conservatives and Republicans look at what happened at Mozilla a few years ago and Brendan Eich ousted from that company for having traditional views on marriage. And then the firing of that engineer of Google.

Is there rampant discrimination in terms of viewpoints against conservatives and how might that play out in terms of average users having information potentially stifled in searches? There are real concerns about that on the right. So, big tech might be waking up these days and saying, uh-oh, we have real problems culturally on the left and the right in this country and that could be a problem for us on Capitol Hill as lawmakers on both sides, rather, start to dig in.

WALLACE: But I want to pick up on something that I asked Speaker Gingrich, because there's no question that these companies have been engines of huge economic growth in this country. Is there a downside to Washington -- obviously there's a downside. How big a downside is there to Washington getting more involved in regulation of the Internet?

BENSON: A huge downside. I think some of the concerns that the speaker raised are fair and reasonable and people would agree with them. My faith in the ability of government to respond to that wealth to regulation is very low. I think it is -- government is slow-moving. It is the opposite of innovative. And the Internet is a miracle. And it wouldn't exist as it does today if the government's clumsy hand had been on its neck from day one. And I think putting more hand on the neck and applying more pressure from D.C., I'm just not sure that works out well.

WALLACE: Fifteen seconds to respond, speaker.

GINGRICH: First of all, the Internet was created by ARPANET, a Department of Defense project. Second, the fact is, there are no time in American history when the huge concentrations of power are not directly challenged by government. And that's overall been good for protecting our liberty.

WALLACE: All right. We'll continue this debate.

This is an important subject and we'll keep talking about it.

Thank you, panel. See you next Sunday.

Up next, our "Power Player of the Week." The doctor who keeps both the Washington Redskins and Nationals healthy, while breaking down barriers in pro sports.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WALLACE: The pro football season is now in full swing. And as we fans dream of how our team will get to the Super Bowl, we know injuries have a way of derailing those hopes, which brings us to our "Power Player of the Week."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DR. ROBIN WEST, HEAD PHYSICIAN, WASHINGTON REDSKINS: In sports medicine, people are very highly motivated so they can play to get better.

WALLACE: Orthopedic surgeon Robin West has a busy schedule. Most of the time she's the head of Inova Sports Medicine in Virginia, except when she's the lead position for both the Washington Redskins and the Washington Nationals.

WALLACE (on camera): What does it mean to you to be the first female head doctor in the history of both major league baseball and the NFL?

WEST: I don't even think about it. I never -- it never really crossed my mind. I -- I never think of myself as different.

WALLACE (voice-over): We saw for ourselves at a Skins exhibition game. Nose tackle Phil Taylor went down on a play and West ran on the field. She examined him there and back on the sidelines for what turned out to be a season ending tear of his left quadriceps muscle.

West told us how different injuries are in the two sports.

WEST: It's over use typically in baseball. We're dealing with a lot of shoulder and elbow injuries in baseball. In football, it's a lot of traumatic injuries, high-energy injuries that we have to really manage quickly.

WALLACE: That's another difference. In baseball, an injured player is out of the game. But in football --

WEST: The coaches are in my ear as I'm examining the kid, is he going to play, is he going to play? I have to decide that pretty quickly.

WALLACE: But West emphasizes how she makes that decision.

WEST: I'm the players' doctor, right? So it's -- I want the best for the player. So, obviously, I work for the -- I don't work for the team, I -- I want the team to do well, but I have to look at the players' best interests.

WALLACE (on camera): Is being a woman an advantage or a disadvantage to doing your job?

WEST: At least in football, a lot of them were raised by their mothers and their grandmothers and so they have -- they hold women in a very high regard and they come to me and will tell me more information and I -- they are very trusting, I think.

WALLACE (voice-over): Dr. West usually does any reconstructive surgeries, but she says psychological outlook is key to getting players back on the field.

WEST: One of my players today, who I operated on last week, he said he's a mental fortress. But yet I have another player who's coming to me and saying, I'm just -- I'm so depressed. I'm not around my team. I -- and they're coming to me and they're asking me for help on the mental side.

WALLACE: Growing up, West was interested in the human body. Her mom noticed.

WEST: When I was five, she got me a "Gray's Anatomy" book for Christmas.

WALLACE (on camera): Why?

WEST: That was my present. I don't know. I just was fascinated by it.

WALLACE: Now the big concern is brain injuries, but she says the NFL has developed a much stricter policy on concussions.

WEST: I think football's the safest it's ever been.

WALLACE: Before Washington, West was an assistant team doctor for the Pittsburgh Steelers and got two Super Bowl rings. Her dream now, to win championships in both football and baseball.

WEST: That's our goal, right? That's everyone's goal on the team is to keep the players healthy and to be as successful as we can. It's a pentacle, and you can't get any better than that.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WALLACE: Dr. West says the Redskins have 15 medical professionals at each game on the field and up in the stands watching to see if any player gets hurt and relaying that information to her.

And that's it for today. Have a great week. And we'll see you next FOX NEWS SUNDAY.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:60XW-5K01-JBCN-4375-00000-00Chronicle recommends: Vote no on Prop. 24, a flawed privacy initiative2020-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisOPINIONChronicle recommends: Vote no on Prop. 24, a flawed privacy initiativeChronicle Editorial Board

Proponents and opponents of Proposition 24 have something in common: Each expresses a fierce determination to toughen privacy protections in California law. We respect the motive and passion of each side.

If the decision on Prop. 24 were merely about the concept — stopping companies from collecting and exploiting personal information about us without our permission or often without our knowledge — it would be an easy call. But this is a complex, legalistic 52-page initiative crafted behind the scenes, including participation of the companies that are the supposed targets of regulation.

It should be evaluated on its details, not merely its good intentions.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation, one of the nation's most aggressive and authoritative champions of privacy rights, has taken a neutral position on Prop. 24. "It is a mixed bag of partial steps backwards and forwards."

That in itself should give voters pause. But several prominent consumer advocacy groups and the American Civil Liberties Union are emphatic in their opposition, arguing that it would weaken state law in some meaningful ways.

To be sure, Prop. 24 has prominent privacy advocates on its side, including Common Sense Media, whose CEO Jim Steyer argues that its creation of the California Privacy Protection Agency (funded with at least $10 million annually) would finally put teeth in the law.

Steyer also likes the provisions that would toughen protections (with triple fines on violations) for consumers under age 16.

Here's how the issue reached the Nov. 3 ballot:

Alastair Mactaggart, a wealthy San Francisco real estate developer, alarmed at learning of the scale of privacy intrusion, was bankrolling a ballot initiative for the November 2018 ballot. He ended up withdrawing the initiative after the California Legislature passed a less sweeping but nevertheless landmark bill known as the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) that year.

The CCPA then encountered intense lobbying from consumer advocates who wanted to strengthen it and businesses that found it too burdensome or difficult to comply with. It survived basically intact and took full effect in July.

Even before the law took effect, Mactaggart worked with Sen. Bob Hertzberg, a Los Angeles Democrat and one of the Capitol's ace deal makers, to forge an initiative that would lock in the CCPA's privacy protections. Mactaggart had seen Big Tech's intensive lobbying in Sacramento and was convinced his brainchild "will not survive in the Legislature without an initiative," which could be undermined only through another statewide vote. Hertzberg said it was the target of a "feeding frenzy of powerful interest groups."

The basic framework of Prop. 24 is solid: give consumers the right to prevent businesses from sharing personal information and the ability to correct errors; prohibit businesses from keeping personal information for longer than necessary; limit the use of especially sensitive information such as race, religion, precise geolocation, union membership, sexual orientation or genetics or health data.

Yet the devil is in the details when it comes to regulating such a dynamic and deep-pocketed sector as the social media and tech giants who are trafficking in personal information.

Analyses by Consumer Reports and the Electronic Frontier Foundation — each neutral on Prop. 24 — characterize it as a missed opportunity to switch the burden from consumers to businesses by requiring the later to obtain permission before scooping, sharing or monetizing personal information, a standard known as "opt in." The initiative maintains an "opt out" standard: keeping the onus on you to protect your personal information.

Another major concern of the privacy advocates opposed to Prop. 24 is that it leaves the door open for "pay for privacy" schemes in which a business could charge users more if they opt out of sharing personal information. Robert Herrell, executive director of the Consumer Federation of California, suggested a few steps forward in the measure are "dwarfed by a number of exemptions and special carveouts."

Few voters will sift through the 52 pages of fine print to determine which side is right. The fact that savvy lawyers on each side of Prop. 24 have done so and come to contrasting conclusions makes one thing clear: Litigation would be certain to follow its passage. Count on this: The companies that are monetizing our personal information in insidious ways would rush to court with their lawyers, and their interpretations, ready to argue that their practices are unaffected by the initiative's language.

And here is one more thing for voters to consider: If Prop. 24 really were as restrictive and airtight as advertised, is there any doubt that those who are exploiting our personal information as a commodity would be pouring tens of millions into defeating it? Their silence is telling.

A good guiding principle for approaching these complicated initiatives is: When in doubt, vote no. It goes against a Californian's instincts to reject what is advertised as a privacy protection initiative, but some objects on the ballot are smaller than they appear. There are no advancements to law in this initiative that could not be enacted by the California Legislature, after public hearings and vetting to assure they actually achieve their intended purpose and the ability to course correct for unintended consequences that emerge.

There is sufficient doubt about Prop. 24 to make the decision clear. Vote no.

This commentary is from The Chronicle's editorial board. We invite you to express your views in a letter to the editor. Please submit your letter via our online form: SFChronicle.com/letters.

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST, breaking news, the "Wall Street Journal" reporting General Motors inked a preliminary deal to sell its Saturn division to mega auto dealer Roger Penske -- details ahead.

And could a shakeup be coming at Citigroup? The Journal reporting Sheila Bair and the FDIC want a change and it could include CEO Vikram Pandit. Who might be tapped to replace him? And what do the people at Citigroup think?

And the SEC charges Mozilo federal regulators charge Countrywide cofounder Angelo Mozilo with insider trading and securities fraud. What will happen to him next?

We're serving these stories and much more this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

Good morning and happy Friday. Welcome to MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. I'm Alexis Glick.

Coming up this morning, much more on the latest on GM Saturn sale and that possible shakeup at Citigroup.

Plus the smart phone war is heating up as Palm gets ready to release its new device; it's called the Pre. And it goes public later today. We'll get a preview of that phone.

And all this as reports that Steve Jobs is ready to return to the helm after a six-month medical hiatus. Could Apple be making a big announcement as early as next week?

Plus, the May unemployment numbers are due out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern time. All eyes are on this number. Expectations are for a loss of another 520,000 jobs; unemployment to reach 9.2 percent. We'll see in just moments.

Roger Ballou, CDI Core President and CEO and Representative Joe Sestak from Pennsylvania are both going to join me to break down those numbers when they come out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern time.

We'll also have a terrific roundtable discussion on where the jobs are being created in the state and local municipalities. Is the fiscal stimulus package actually helping create enough jobs?

Let's take a look at the futures right now as we get started. As you can see across the board we're in the green; right now the DOW up 36; S&P up four; NASDAQ up three. So across the board we're up just fractionally.

Let's get directly to the markets. Fox Business contributor Gavin Gray is in for Mr. Ashley Webster in London. And Connell McShane is here with us right now. Let's get started with Connell here in New York -- Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning Alexis. Yes we're certainly watching those markets closely, you showed us the futures moving a little bit higher indicating we might get a higher open at the final trading day of the week.

But all of that can change of course; 8:30 a.m. Eastern time will be the big number on jobs. Now, speaking of jobs in a different -- speaking of it in a different way, Steve Jobs is making big news at Apple.

The "Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting he is on pace to take back the CEO position to come back on to the job as planned and with that said, from medical leave, the stock is getting a nice boost this morning.

All of that kind of plays into what Alexis was talking about a little while ago, the back and forth between Apple and Palm; Palm coming out over the weekend with its Pre. Not only might jobs come back as planned here but the idea is maybe he comes back a little earlier than planned.

There's a big developer's conference next week and the thinking is maybe Jobs comes back for that, announces a new iPhone. We'll see that getting a little bit ahead of ourselves but the "Journal" starting that speculation this morning.

Investors seem to like it. The Apple stock price as you see there up to 147 in change pre-market trading.

Ok, let's see what the European markets are up to this morning as we do now head over to Gavin Gray in London -- Gavin.

GAVIN GRAY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Connell thanks very much indeed. Let's first of all have a look at the markets over here; all really waiting on particularly in Europe and Britain waiting really for the results of the cabinet reshuffle.

But let's kick off in London with the FTSE. That is currently up 67 points leading the way at 4,454; the CAC-40 now gaining of a bit of strength as well, up 28 points. And the DAX really hasn't moved much all morning. Just up 21 points or 0.4 of a percent.

As really as I said, eyes looking at Downing Street, waiting for this Cabinet reshuffle. We haven't had it confirmed yet but we do believe that the Alistair Darling who is the current Chancellor -- the moneyman is going to keep his position. It's rumored he told Gordon Brown I either have this job or I don't have a job in your cabinet. We do think that he is going to remain as Chancellor. One or two other movements, we believe a fourth Minister has resigned. That is the fourth in just four days.

And also a report that U.K. inflation continues to fall. A sign about that the Office of National Statistics says the price of manufactured goods has come down just 0.3 percent year on year, largely because of the oil price coming down in that last year, but of course oil is coming back up. But that is the biggest annual decline since June 2002.

Alexis back to you.

GLICK: All right, Gavin thank you very much.

Well, auto news now. It is a hot topic.

Breaking news this morning the "Wall Street Journal" says auto dealer Roger Penske will reportedly buy the Saturn brand from General Motors. Sources say, Penske would buy vehicles from GM and Renault then sell them under the Saturn brand. No word yet on how much Penske is paying. An official announcement is to be made later today.

And the deal to sell Hummer to a Chinese company may have hit a bump in the road. Some experts say regulators in Beijing may block it because the Hummer brand goes against China's focus on fuel efficient vehicles.

And GM will finance a huge part of a private equity firm's buyout of parts maker Delphi. GM will provide $2.5 billion of the $3.6 billion -- that specific $3.6 billion price tag. In return GM buys back four Delphi plants.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL PACINO, ACTOR: Something really wrong is going on here.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You are out of order.

PACINO: You're out of order, you're out of order. The whole trial is out of order. They are out of order.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GLICK: And there you have it. That was Al Pacino. I'm not sure if you remember in the courtroom black comedy "And Justice For All" which details chaos in the court system. And some think that's precisely what's going on today with the Chrysler bankruptcy hearing.

A judge in New York will hear arguments from a group trying to block the deal with Fiat. Opponents include a group of Indiana state pension funds and a dozen other parties.

Speaking of which, for more on what we can expect today, let's go directly down to lower Manhattan to our own Adam Shapiro who is standing outside the U.S. Court of Appeals.

And Adam I'm not sure it's quite Al Pacino style but it seems like it's getting pretty close.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, it could be close, but the Indiana - - the lawyers for the Indiana State Treasurer Richard Murdock are going to be arguing on behalf of 100,000 Indiana pensioners, police officers as well as teachers that the sale to Fiat violates all kinds of bankruptcy law as well as the TARP law -- the law which created the Trouble Asset Relief Program. That's the argument they're going to make in court.

First, that senior secured lenders like the pensioners are being given a secondary position in this bankruptcy which is counter to Bankruptcy Law. Second, that the TARP was originally created to help financial institutions not automobile companies and that's a violation of the Troubled Asset Relief Program that was set up last year.

And that third, this is just a deal that is not good for the U.S. taxpayers. That's the argument they're going to make in court. And that argument lost. They didn't gain any ground with that argument when they presented it to Judge Arthur Gonzalez at the Bankruptcy Court.

They've also argued that this was a private plan agreed to before, they called it a Sub-Rosa plan, before Chrysler filed for bankruptcy, but again, Arthur Gonzalez said no that's just not the case. That's what the Appellate panel is going to hear; the three judges on the Appellate Court.

They're also going to be considering Chrysler's motion to certify the sale. If that happens, if the Indiana pensioners lose and Chrysler wins and the sale is certified, you can expect that sale to close almost immediately because Chrysler says it has to close the deal with Fiat by the 15th of June or else Fiat has the option to walk away from the table and worse it walks away with $35 million from Chrysler as a penalty for failing to close the deal.

So there's a lot riding on this decision today, Alexis.

One other thing in regards to that Hummer sale and the report that the Chinese are making perhaps a problem as to closing that deal because Hummers aren't fuel efficient. Hummer dealers will tell you that the H-3 which is the smaller Hummer -- it's built on the Chevy Colorado platform -- they'll tell you it gets better gas mileage on the highway than some of the import SUVs like the Lexus. So that's an argument that they are probably ready to fight.

Back to you.

GLICK: All right, Adam. I was just going to ask you about that, I appreciate it. All right, we'll check in with you a little later outside the court.

All right, well Chrysler is fighting two courtroom battles which Adam just talked about in its push to exit bankruptcy and merge with Fiat. In addition to today's hearing with the group of those Indiana state pensions and investment funds that are looking to block the deal. Close to 800 of the Chrysler's dealers are making their case in court. They made it yesterday to put the breaks on the plan.

For a closer look at the impact of the courtroom battles, Laurie Moncrieff is the president of Schmald Tool & Die, an auto parts supplier that did business for Chrysler, and joining us on the phone Jim Anderer, the owner of Island Jeep in Long Island who is fighting in court to keep his business open.

Laurie, don't worry about the people behind you. I saw you telling people to keep quiet. Believe me I do that every single day. All right Laurie, tell me first of all, what does this delay mean to you and your business?

LAURIE MONCRIEFF, PRESIDENT, SCHMALD TOOL & DIE: The manufacturers have been feeling the effects of what's been happening in the auto industry for quite some time. So quite frankly we're ready to get on with business.

The markets up here have been largely frozen because of what's going on in our economy in Michigan with the Detroit three. So in our opinion, we feel that moving forward quickly with the bankruptcy would be a help to the manufacturers.

GLICK: And Laurie, explain specifically what it is that you guys do and sort of where you fit into the food chain here in terms of how this impacts your business.

MONCRIEFF: We do precision machining and make dyes for the auto industry as well as many other industries. And quite frankly, all this upheaval is affecting a lot of industries besides just the auto industry.

GLICK: Great point.

Jim, I know you're joining us by phone. You've been kind enough to be here on several occasions. You're fighting to keep your dealership alive. You are one of those who received a pink slip. Tell me why the delay of this judgment of this decision could actually help you.

JIM ANDERER, PRESIDENT, ISLAND JEEP (via telephone): Hi, Alexis. Well, thanks for having me.

The delay helps me only in regard that it can possibly nix this deal. This is a bad deal for the American taxpayer. It's a bad deal for pretty much everybody involved, in my opinion.

I know that the vendor on the other line, you know, has her own agenda, and I'm sympathetic to that. But in my personal opinion this is a tragedy that's taking place in the American marketplace. It's putting 100,000 people out of work. It's really devastating to our economy right now. And I would like to see it nixed to be honest with you. I don't think it's a good deal...

GLICK: Ok, so Jim...

ANDERER: I think that Fiat is coming into this deal with no cash. And it's wrought with a lot of problems.

GLICK: Jim, you and I have talked about this before, and you have been in the courtroom. In fact you were in the courtroom yesterday speaking on behalf of those dealers who are being forced to shut down.

What convinces you that if the deal were not to go through with Fiat, that a liquidation of Chrysler would put you in a better position than if this deal were to go through?

ANDERER: Very simply that the market forces that would take place is exactly what should take place. The market forces would seek their own level which is the way it should be.

Ok, what's going on with this taxpayer bailout and all this other stuff? I mean, you know, give me a break. If -- whatever these particular brands are worth when they're in liquidation would be sold for what they are worth.

Ok I'm a stand-alone Jeep store. Jeep is never going to go away. It is going to be picked up by somebody. And whoever that is, is going to make a real go of it. But there's a false propping up of these brands is insanity. This is just not the way things should be done in a free marketplace.

GLICK: Laurie, let me switch to you for a moment. You actually feel that if they can make it through bankruptcy, that as suppliers, your position will be that much safer and more secure. Explain to people why that is.

LAURIE MONCRIEFF, PRESIDENT, SCHMALD TOOL & DIE: Well, it's always a lot more risky to do business with a company prior to bankruptcy than after bankruptcy so we felt a huge disruption, and quite frankly in the tool and die industry, we felt a huge disruption for many, many years and we've seen this coming for many years.

We've known there's been instability in the market for many years. We were somewhat of the canary in the mines frankly in this economy and have been discussing the problems in tooling and in manufacturing since the early 2000 because we could feel that it was very unstable, and that the economy was not doing well quite frankly in the early 2002, 2003.

There were a lot of discussions about the problems in the market. So while many of the dealers and other segments of the auto industry quite frankly probably weren't even aware of the problems we were very much aware of it in our industry.

GLICK: So Laurie when you look at the current environment, I mean look, you live in Flint, Michigan. We're actually going to talk to Virg Bernero a little bit later on this morning.

What are people doing right now to either make sure that companies like you are diversifying your risk or finding other viable job opportunities because I imagine everything is tightened up in Michigan?

MONCRIEFF: Everything's not only tightened up. It's frozen in the market right now. And it's not just the auto industry, it's the financial markets are really playing a huge role. The state of Michigan has been basically red lined by a lot of banks so lines of credit are being pulled, very much a big problem with getting financing to operate your business.

And then even in other industries when you diversify, we're feeling a lot of difficulty in a lot of other industries that are not even part of the auto industry because the financial market up in Michigan is frozen, as I said. So we're very anxious for the market to be unfrozen, whatever it takes to do that.

We need financing. We need money to start flowing to survive. That's basically what we're doing up here in Flint is working very, very hard to survive this right now.

GLICK: All right. Well, Laurie, we wish you the very best. And Jim, you too. Thank you guys so much for taking the time to join us this morning.

ANDERER: Thanks, Alexis.

MONCRIEFF: Thank you.

GLICK: Coming up, Countrywide's cofounder Angelo Mozilo charged with fraud by the SEC. The Judge is going to join us with his take.

And later the Palm Pre hits stores tomorrow. Will it take a bite out of Apple's iPhone? There's a lot of buzz about this. We're going to tell you about it in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: In court now, two executives from a defunct Seattle investment management firm are charged with running what prosecutors call one of the largest tax fraud schemes ever uncovered in the country. Quellos founder, Matthew Krane and CEO Jeffrey Greenstein and two others are charged with fraud, tax evasion and money laundering. Prosecutors say they created more than $1.3 billion in fraudulent losses for clients. Quellos used to be one of the world's biggest managers of mutual funds.

A jury not a judge will hear claims in a case between American International Group, AIG and Star International, the company controlled by Maurice Greenberg AIG's former CEO. The trial will now start June 15th. There are several lawsuits outstanding between AIG and Mr. Greenberg and sure wants Star to return AIG stocks and proceeds from stock sales. AIG received billions of dollars in federal bailout funds.

And the Securities and Exchange Commission charges former Countrywide CEO Angelo Mozilo with fraud and insider trading. Prosecutors say Mozilo and two other former executives misled investors about risky lending practices. The SEC also says Mozilo unloaded $140 million in Countrywide stock using insider information. It is the first case against a high-profile executive stemming from the sub prime mortgage meltdown. Mozilo has denied any wrongdoing and his lawyer calls the SEC's allegations baseless.

Our fox news senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano joins us right now for a look at the case. The judge is in the house and he's going to give us some explanations here. Judge, good to see you.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Good morning Alexis. Good to see you.

GLICK: surprised by this announcement?

NAPOLITANO: I'm surprised by this announcement. I expected -- and that would be standard operating procedure in a case like this -- an indictment rather than a civil lawsuit. This is a civil lawsuit the Securities and Exchange Commission says you didn't tell your opinion of your own products to your shareholders, and that caused them to acquire shares ignorant of what you thought of the products.

What did he think of them? Well the SEC got some e-mails, and in that he referred to his own products as toxic and poison. Now, that's the bad news that he said that in these e-mails. The good news for him is he was not indicted. He was not charged with a crime. The feds may still be investigating for that purpose.

But standard operating procedure in cases of fraud and insider trading is to indict and convict first and then to sue civilly. So the fact that they are suing him civilly, they are just looking for money and an order from a judge that he can never run a public company again. They are not looking to take away his freedom, tells me they don't have enough evidence to indict him or convict him.

GLICK: It's interesting because involved in this case also being charged with this as well is his chief operating officer and the CFO. All three of which are saying that number one, it's baseless. That they did divulge the proper information throughout the entire reporting process, and they say look the fact of the matter is the SEC has not done anything right in years, and they are using them as the poster child for what the SEC should have done over the past five years.

NAPOLITANO: Well, the SEC's failures is a political argument that the court will not allow them to make to a jury. But the court will let them say this, "Look, you have accused us of failing to share our opinions with everyone. You haven't us accused of failing to share facts."

This is not Enron or WorldCom where inaccurate data was given out. This is just a case where an opinion like toxic and poison wasn't shared with the public.

GLICK: Ok, but what is the chance, though, that when you read what the SEC is suggesting here, that this is brought on to suggest that it is very much like an Enron case, where they were not divulging material public information that could have affected decisions of shareholders, investors, etc.?

NAPOLITANO: It is a question of law for the court to decide. Is it material information what the CEO's personal opinion is of his products? These are not facts now. They didn't hide numbers. They didn't cook books. They just held back these words like toxic and poison.

Flip side of this is, if this was really insider trading, they would have indicted him. But because they haven't indicted him, what it is, is using insider knowledge to sell; knowledge that anyone else could have gotten had they looked into the books.

GLICK: Let's bring up one of those e-mails dating back to 2006 because I want people to hear specifically what he said. "In all my years in the business, I have never seen a more toxic product." That was one e-mail.

He also sent another e-mail regarding a certain kind of sub prime loan. And he said "it is the most dangerous product in existence, and there can be nothing more toxic. Loans had been originated through our channels with disregard for process and compliance with guidelines." This is where he's talking about the fact that the procedure for getting loans was just way too simple.

NAPOLITANO: You know what the defense is? "The government wanted us to do this and Fannie and Freddie took them off our backs and the shareholders are no longer at risk." That's the defense that he'll make and that's true.

The government did want those subprime loans given out and Fannie and Freddie did take them off the backs of Countrywide and others. That is inappropriate in my view believing in a free market. That's what the government did and that's why we have this crisis.

GLICK: Let's talk about one of the domino effects here. There's no doubt in my mind that Senator Christopher Dodd is climbing in a shell, perhaps in a bunker, as a result of this. He was one of those on the sort of Mozilo list of getting what some argue is a better mortgage. What do you make of this for Dodd?

NAPOLITANO: This is very bad news for Chris Dodd who already is suffering politically in Connecticut as a result of this. He's up for reelection in 2010.

Just as Angelo Mozilo kept from shareholders his opinion of his own product, Chris Dodd kept from voters the fact that Angelo Mozilo gave him an absolute sweetheart deal.

What's the relationship between Chris Dodd and Angelo Mozilo? Chris Dodd is the chairman of the senate banking committee which regulates these things and writes the laws to control them. And he's accepting an enormous benefit that the public could never get from the CEO of one of the biggest companies he's writing the laws to regulate. The voters of Connecticut will have their say on this one, Alexis.

GLICK: Yes, this is ugly. And then that whole issue with the AIG, the wording of the bonuses and the fiscal stimulus package. Oh my goodness.

NAPOLITANO: Senator Dodd's also deep into that one.

GLICK: Yes. Judge, thank you very much. Great seeing you.

NAPOLITANO: Happy Friday. Have a great weekend.

GLICK: Happy Friday.

Also again I do want to say Mozilo has denied any wrongdoing and his lawyer David Siegel calls the SEC allegations baseless. As for the other defendants, they attorney for David Sambol called this "a baseless complaint that is a result of the political pressure the SEC is facing for the well-publicized enforcement failures."

And Eric Sieracki's attorney meanwhile says the SEC's case is "without merit. Countrywide's stock performance was tied to the fortunes of the real estate and secondary markets for loans. Something all investors knew about."

I just wanted to clear up some statements from their attorneys.

Coming up, Charles Payne offers up his stock choices.

And President Obama meeting with German chancellor Angela Merkel today; the president reassured the Europeans about the U.S. economy. We will tell you what he had to say when MONEY FOR BREAKFAST returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GAVIN GRAY, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Welcome back to MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. I'm Gavin Gray with a look at this morning's top news stories.

President Obama is meeting with the German Chancellor Angela Merkel today after bilateral meeting addressed in castle (ph), President Obama held a joint press conference with the German chancellor. The president reassured the Europeans about the U.S. economy. Take a listen to what he had to say here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: In the United States we are working diligently to strengthen financial regulations, to ensure that a crisis like this doesn't happen again. And it is going to be very important to coordinate between Europe and the United States as we move to strengthen our financial regulatory systems.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GRAY: He'll be visiting Buchenwald concentration camp this morning. Before leaving for Paris, president Obama will meet with wounded soldiers at Landstuhl Medical Center.

In other news, investigators -- or rather reports of a setback for the search for Air France flight 447. France's Transportation Minister says French forces have found no evidence of an Airbus A-330 airplane that vanished over the Atlantic. He's urging extreme prudence about suspected debris fished from the ocean. The French Transportation Minister says he regrets an announcement by Brazilian teams that they had recovered plane debris from Air France flight 447. The jetliner was flying from Rio de Janeiro to Paris; 228 people were on board.

AFP is reporting that former vice president Al Gore may be sent to North Korea to negotiate the release of two American journalists. Laura Ling and Euna Lee were arrested on March 17th near the North Korean border on charges they entered the country illegally and were engaged in hostile acts. Both women are reporters for Gore's California-based Current TV. They each could be sentenced to ten years in a labor camp.

You are up-to-date on the Fox Business Network.

Now back to New York and Charles Payne for a look at the stocks he's watching -- Charles, I'm listening.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you so much Gavin really appreciate it. Well folks it's going to be an exciting day today. Hopefully we will be to the upside.

A couple of stocks three stocks we're looking at. Manitowoc is one. This is one of these real hot equipment making stocks that obviously because of the economy has gotten hit real good. I think your risk reward now is really, really nice. Right here is where it broke the trend line recently. Now we're looking at a little resistance right around $7.80.

A break out there and I think you are pretty good. That takes you right here, that would be north of 10 buck; a huge percentage play. I love the fact that the risk reward is pretty good. In the March quarter they beat the street by almost 30 percent. Maybe that business is turning around. Certainly, the chart is attractive here.

Sina, I've probably mentioned this one now at least five times in the last year. As you can see, it is really starting to come on here to the point where it looks extremely, extremely attractive. This stock is breaking key resistance. I love the volume on it. I think if you don't have any China stocks, Baidu is my favorite. A lot of people are afraid to buy a stock that's almost $300 a share. This one might have room all the way up to $47 a share. It is one to take a look at. It is a reiteration.

And finally the stock that caught my eye more than any other yesterday. A company called Flir. The chart isn't so hot necessarily, it's been going down for a long time but I think it's hit a bottom and I think it's on the cusp of a major breakout.

By the way, this company has beaten the Street in each of the last four quarters and each time they beat by a larger margin. They make imaging systems for the military and of course for commercial use. I think the stock has room to $32 that would be almost 50 percent gain. I love the way it looked yesterday.

By the way, I have one pick on the Web that you have to go and take a look at today. Fox Business.com/moneyforbreakfast.

GLICK: All right, Mr. Payne, I look forward to it.

PAYNE: I'm pumped up about today, I'm hoping under 500,000. Keep our fingers crossed.

GLICK: Let's hope it is not too bad. Thank you very much Charles.

Coming up, we're going to go live to London for a look on how the overseas markets are trading. And Palm looking to take a bite out of Apple's bottom line with its new smart phone called the Pre. We're going to get a real live demonstration right here in studio and tell you why there's a lot of buzz about it. That's coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, and welcome back to MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. I'm Alexis Glick.

Coming up: More on a report this morning from "The Wall Street Journal" that the FDIC is pushing for a shakeup of Citigroup's top management, including CEO Vikram Pandit. We're going to see who was mentioned as a possible replacement.

And Palm gets ready to release its Pre device tomorrow, looking to steal some of the success from Apple's iPhone. We're going to preview it in just a couple of minutes.

And what movie could possibly take down Pixar's "Up" from the top spot? Well, Universal and Warner Brothers have new releases. We're going to get those expectations both coming out today.

And we have the May employment report due out at 8:30. The expectation is for a loss of 520,000 jobs. We'll be live at the Labor Department.

And then, coming up on "THE OPENING BELL" at 9:35 a.m., I will be speaking with Labor Secretary Hilda Solis and get her reaction on the First on FOX to those job numbers.

All right. Let's take a look at the futures. We've been in the green throughout the morning. Let's see, are we still in the green? We are. OK, good news.

We're actually a little bit higher earlier this morning. The Dow up 41, S&P up 5, NASDAQ up 5 as well. So, looking pretty good.

Let's get directly to financial news though -- we got a lot of that news. The FDIC is putting pressure on Citigroup to make some changes in its boardroom. "The Wall Street Journal" says CEO Vikram Pandit could be bounced out. "The Journal" says officials reached out to former U.S. Bancorp CEO, Jerry Grundhofer to see if he wanted the job. The Feds own 34 percent of Citigroup.

And the FDIC is putting its program to rid the nation's banks of toxic assets on hold. The Legacy Loans Program was supposed to begin with trial sale this month, the FDIC says banks have proven they can raise private capital without cleansing their balance sheets. I think that the information systems companies now used to control their inventories and their production capacity led them to react much, much more quickly. What I think that's going to lead to is a slower sustained recovery coming out of this, so it's going to be like a reverse hockey stick, where you saw a quicker downtick, but a gradual uptick that will come.

I also agree that I think the financial programs are the key driver of the uptick here. I don't think that much of the stimulus has kicked in yet, so I suspect that the bigger stimulus effect here has been the credit markets opening up, and that leading to enhanced consumer confidence and business confidence.

The other thing that's gone on is the global economy, where you see the Indian economy continuing to grow very, very strongly. You see the Chinese economy in resurgence based on their stimulus programs. So I think those things are contributing significantly to the uptick as well.

So, it is an interconnected global economy. In our case, I think the financial programs have been very, very critical to it. I also think the president himself has been instilling confidence through his communication, through his demeanor, through the programs that he's launched. And this is a very -- you know, people's psyches are fragile, but they also can move in a positive direction, very, very quickly, and I think you are beginning to see that occurring.

GLICK: Congressman Sestak, I'm going to give you the last word.

One of the things about the data shows that number of hours worked have dropped. Productivity, as we just saw yesterday, is rising.

One material concern out there is that we will see declining wages, that we've seen declining wages, but that it will be a bigger issue that the consumer will still remain fairly tapped out. And because we've figured out how to accomplish more with less workers, that some of those jobs may not come back.

How important is it to find those future jobs that will perhaps replace a lot of the millions of jobs of the six million that we have seen since the recession began?

SESTAK: This is an excellent point you make.

We have lost about a trillion dollars in our GDP as compared to our 2007 GDP high peak. And if we just have an economy, as was just mentioned, that grows slowly, and let's just say it grows at 2.5 percent, which was the average between 2001 and 2007, it will take us three years to soak up that $1 trillion of lost GDP capacity. Which means if we don't grow more rapidly, we won't be creating these jobs that you spoke about.

That's why the president's budget is absolutely critical. If he is -- and I believe he is -- intent upon in succeeding in retooling the economy in the types of jobs, the green energy jobs, the ability to reform our health care system, those parts of this budget will be absolutely critical.

Second, I go back that we have to do more in the entrepreneur incentives by the right tax incentives to get that extra bump to our economy above 2.5 percent growth in the next few years to come, or we won't create those jobs.

GLICK: Right. Good point.

SESTAK: Because China is growing this year 6.8 percent as we lose about five or six percent. So that's why this is important, your point.

GLICK: All right, guys. We are going to leave it there. Terrific, terrific discussion.

I'm glad to see we've seen some relief in the numbers, but remember still a lot of people unemployed in this economy.

Congressman Sestak, Roger and John, thank you so much, gentlemen.

SESTAK: Thank you for having me.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you.

GLICK: A reminder, by the way please join me, 9:35 a.m. Eastern Time. I will be speaking to the labor secretary, Hilda Solis, in a "First on Fox" interview here to break down this May employment number. So please tune in for that. We'll get an opportunity to get her thoughts in just about 45 minutes.

All right. Coming up, more jobs lost. We're talking to students just entering the working world about their hunt for employment.

And of course we will head live to the New York Stock Exchange for a little bit of a preview on what is now a market that's looking pretty good.

We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All week we have been taking a look at the nation's growing deficit as a result of government spending as something we called red ink. Now, MONEY FOR BREAKFAST teamed up with the college news service U-Wire to take a closer look at Generation Debt, the students of America who will inherit the current deficit

Some of those students told us the financial worries that are keeping them -- frankly, they're keeping them up at night. Take a listen to what they had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My biggest financial concern is just to find a job after I graduate.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm more worried about people my parents' age who have just seen their retirement funds completely be gone.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My parents' businesses since December, like, their sales have been halved. And that kind of really affects me because I'm in school now. I can't help them out.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My personal biggest financial concern is just being able to live the life that we're expected to live as -- you know, again since I came from a background where my parents didn't necessarily have a lot of money, I think there was a big expectation for me coming to college and getting the job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GLICK: Well, as you heard, some of the students we spoke to say finding a job is their top worry. With roughly 1.5 million graduating seniors entering the workforce this year and a loss of another 500,000 -- well, now actually we have seen 350,000 jobs in May, according to the most recent survey -- what will they do? And is now the time to figure out other options?

Joining us right now, Emily Sutherland, who is heading into her senior year at Colorado State; Leah Finnegan, who graduated from the University of Texas this year; and Dean Van Tassell, who received his MBA from Pace University just two weeks ago.

Good morning, guys. Good to see you.

LEAH FINNEGAN, UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS GRADUATE: Good morning.

DEAN VAN TASSELL, RECEIVED MBA FROM PACE UNIVERSITY: Good morning.

EMILY SUTHERLAND, HEADING INTO SENIOR YEAR AT COLORADO STATE: Good morning.

GLICK: All right, Dean. Let me talk to you.

You just graduated two weeks ago from Pace University. You have been on the job hunt. What have you been experiencing?

VAN TASSELL: Well, first of all, thank you for having me on the program. And BB&T Capital Markets loves Fox Business.

GLICK: Oh, that's good to know. Thanks.

VAN TASSELL: I have been applying to, let's see now, about 70 different investment banks, writing the HR departments, following with managing directors, trying to get my name out there as much as possible. I have a nice stack of rejection letters right now, so it's rough out there.

You know, you have to start making contingency plans. And it's -- you know, we're up to 9.4 percent. The only solace I have is that maybe the 9.4 percent unemployment is backwards looking, and the market seems to be shrugging it off today. So hopefully we will have second derivative fever and things will start to level out and pick up relatively soon.

GLICK: Leah, you just graduated from the University of Texas. You have a BA in American studies.

What kind of jobs have you been looking for?

FINNEGAN: I'm actually going into journalism, which is, you know, quite an experience at this time. And I applied to about 20 jobs, and I heard "No" from about five. And then I just didn't hear from the rest of them. So it's kind of like applying to a black hole.

GLICK: Yes, radio silence.

So what did you decide to do when you just weren't getting back any responses or you were just getting rejection notes without even, as I understand, getting an opportunity to even interview?

FINNEGAN: Well, my contingency plan was grad school, and I wasn't sure if I wanted to go, and kind of applied on the lark and ended up getting into grad school and not getting into any jobs. So grad school it is.

GLICK: So you're going to Columbia?

FINNEGAN: Yes.

GLICK: My alma mater.

FINNEGAN: Oh, OK.

GLICK: Very excited. OK.

Now Emily, let me talk to you. I understand you are majoring in communications. You are going to be a senior this year at Colorado State.

When you listen to what's happening to Dean and Leah and I'm sure a lot of your other classmates, how is that impacting you? How nervous does it make you knowing that you are going into your senior year of college?

SUTHERLAND: Well, it makes me really nervous, of course. A lot of my friends have graduated. A lot of them have resulted in working at Starbucks and their degree has gotten them absolutely nowhere. So I just hope that things pick up so I actually do have job opportunities out there once I graduate.

GLICK: Dean, you smiled there. I mean, how many of your friends and colleagues have had to do that? Like, you might have had aspirations of working on Wall Street or working in a particular sector, but there's no opportunities and you have to get what you can get.

VAN TASSELL: I know a lot of people who would be lucky to get a job at Starbucks. It's hard.

I will probably have to go back to bartending for a little bit, but it seem just as competitive as Wall Street, if not more. You have a lot of people laid off and in the same position I'm in, so a lot of people just don't have any options, even contingency plans.

The number one thing I hear is there's a lot of government jobs out there, but the mentality of, I want to work on Wall Street, I'm very aggressive, I want to be in the financial markets than going into a government job, it's a bit different from what you have expected might be around after you graduate. So...

GLICK: Right.

And Leah, how many other classmates of yours have said they are going to choose to continue to go back to school because that's really the only and best option?

FINNEGAN: A really good number. It is a very popular option right now. And I don't know, I'm kind of finding the whole experience a bit freeing, and I think a lot of people my peers are as well, that now we have this time right now to kind of relax and discover what we really want to do.

GLICK: Good point.

FINNEGAN: and then we have the rest of our lives to do it. So there's not so much pressure to be successful and make more than $100,000 right out of college.

GLICK: Great point.

I wish you all the best success. Leah, Dean and Emily, thank you guys so much.

VAN TASSELL: Thank you.

FINNEGAN: Thank you.

SUTHERLAND: Thank you.

GLICK: All right, guys. We're going to take a break. We will be right back with "THE OPENING BELL" in just a moment. We're just about five minutes away.

All right. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Welcome back. It's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

Connell, you were watching actually the bond market reaction to the jobs data. What did you see happen?

MCSHANE: Well, a big move up in yields, which is really going to be the story that we're going to have to follow very, very closely, Alexis, when you think about it.

And Charles, you and I talked about this, the idea that hey, maybe the economy has bottomed out and things are starting to look better, but what about rising yields, rising mortgage rates, and other things? And does that cut off the recovery?

GLICK: It could be a tough bear market for the bonds.

PAYNE: Absolutely. And also, I was looking at equities. I thought the Dow and this type of number would be up 200, 300 points. I'm serious. I think we have a conflict here with the unemployment number being 9.4.

GLICK: I agree.

PAYNE: Two separate surveys -- the Household Survey saying, listen, it's tough, it's tougher than the way the businesses maybe are looking at it.

GLICK: Yes. You've got to wonder why the divergence.

And speaking of which, actually, I'm going to talk to Labor Secretary Hilda Solis coming up on "THE OPENING BELL," 9:35 a.m. Eastern Time. So tune in. She will he' be joining us "First on Fox."

All right, guys. We'll be right back.

END
