urn:contentItem:7W6C-99X0-YBK5-D0YS-00000-00Chrysler-Fiat Deal Appeal; SEC Charges Mozilo; Pulse of Employment; Board Shake Up at Citi; No Opel Launch in US; Groups Trying to Block2009-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisChrysler-Fiat Deal Appeal; SEC Charges Mozilo; Pulse of Employment; Board Shake Up at Citi; No Opel Launch in US; Groups Trying to Block

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST, breaking news, the "Wall Street Journal" reporting General Motors inked a preliminary deal to sell its Saturn division to mega auto dealer Roger Penske -- details ahead.

And could a shakeup be coming at Citigroup? The Journal reporting Sheila Bair and the FDIC want a change and it could include CEO Vikram Pandit. Who might be tapped to replace him? And what do the people at Citigroup think?

And the SEC charges Mozilo federal regulators charge Countrywide cofounder Angelo Mozilo with insider trading and securities fraud. What will happen to him next?

We're serving these stories and much more this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

Good morning and happy Friday. Welcome to MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. I'm Alexis Glick.

Coming up this morning, much more on the latest on GM Saturn sale and that possible shakeup at Citigroup.

Plus the smart phone war is heating up as Palm gets ready to release its new device; it's called the Pre. And it goes public later today. We'll get a preview of that phone.

And all this as reports that Steve Jobs is ready to return to the helm after a six-month medical hiatus. Could Apple be making a big announcement as early as next week?

Plus, the May unemployment numbers are due out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern time. All eyes are on this number. Expectations are for a loss of another 520,000 jobs; unemployment to reach 9.2 percent. We'll see in just moments.

Roger Ballou, CDI Core President and CEO and Representative Joe Sestak from Pennsylvania are both going to join me to break down those numbers when they come out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern time.

We'll also have a terrific roundtable discussion on where the jobs are being created in the state and local municipalities. Is the fiscal stimulus package actually helping create enough jobs?

Let's take a look at the futures right now as we get started. As you can see across the board we're in the green; right now the DOW up 36; S&P up four; NASDAQ up three. So across the board we're up just fractionally.

Let's get directly to the markets. Fox Business contributor Gavin Gray is in for Mr. Ashley Webster in London. And Connell McShane is here with us right now. Let's get started with Connell here in New York -- Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning Alexis. Yes we're certainly watching those markets closely, you showed us the futures moving a little bit higher indicating we might get a higher open at the final trading day of the week.

But all of that can change of course; 8:30 a.m. Eastern time will be the big number on jobs. Now, speaking of jobs in a different -- speaking of it in a different way, Steve Jobs is making big news at Apple.

The "Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting he is on pace to take back the CEO position to come back on to the job as planned and with that said, from medical leave, the stock is getting a nice boost this morning.

All of that kind of plays into what Alexis was talking about a little while ago, the back and forth between Apple and Palm; Palm coming out over the weekend with its Pre. Not only might jobs come back as planned here but the idea is maybe he comes back a little earlier than planned.

There's a big developer's conference next week and the thinking is maybe Jobs comes back for that, announces a new iPhone. We'll see that getting a little bit ahead of ourselves but the "Journal" starting that speculation this morning.

Investors seem to like it. The Apple stock price as you see there up to 147 in change pre-market trading.

Ok, let's see what the European markets are up to this morning as we do now head over to Gavin Gray in London -- Gavin.

GAVIN GRAY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Connell thanks very much indeed. Let's first of all have a look at the markets over here; all really waiting on particularly in Europe and Britain waiting really for the results of the cabinet reshuffle.

But let's kick off in London with the FTSE. That is currently up 67 points leading the way at 4,454; the CAC-40 now gaining of a bit of strength as well, up 28 points. And the DAX really hasn't moved much all morning. Just up 21 points or 0.4 of a percent.

As really as I said, eyes looking at Downing Street, waiting for this Cabinet reshuffle. We haven't had it confirmed yet but we do believe that the Alistair Darling who is the current Chancellor -- the moneyman is going to keep his position. It's rumored he told Gordon Brown I either have this job or I don't have a job in your cabinet. We do think that he is going to remain as Chancellor. One or two other movements, we believe a fourth Minister has resigned. That is the fourth in just four days.

And also a report that U.K. inflation continues to fall. A sign about that the Office of National Statistics says the price of manufactured goods has come down just 0.3 percent year on year, largely because of the oil price coming down in that last year, but of course oil is coming back up. But that is the biggest annual decline since June 2002.

Alexis back to you.

GLICK: All right, Gavin thank you very much.

Well, auto news now. It is a hot topic.

Breaking news this morning the "Wall Street Journal" says auto dealer Roger Penske will reportedly buy the Saturn brand from General Motors. Sources say, Penske would buy vehicles from GM and Renault then sell them under the Saturn brand. No word yet on how much Penske is paying. An official announcement is to be made later today.

And the deal to sell Hummer to a Chinese company may have hit a bump in the road. Some experts say regulators in Beijing may block it because the Hummer brand goes against China's focus on fuel efficient vehicles.

And GM will finance a huge part of a private equity firm's buyout of parts maker Delphi. GM will provide $2.5 billion of the $3.6 billion -- that specific $3.6 billion price tag. In return GM buys back four Delphi plants.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL PACINO, ACTOR: Something really wrong is going on here.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You are out of order.

PACINO: You're out of order, you're out of order. The whole trial is out of order. They are out of order.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GLICK: And there you have it. That was Al Pacino. I'm not sure if you remember in the courtroom black comedy "And Justice For All" which details chaos in the court system. And some think that's precisely what's going on today with the Chrysler bankruptcy hearing.

A judge in New York will hear arguments from a group trying to block the deal with Fiat. Opponents include a group of Indiana state pension funds and a dozen other parties.

Speaking of which, for more on what we can expect today, let's go directly down to lower Manhattan to our own Adam Shapiro who is standing outside the U.S. Court of Appeals.

And Adam I'm not sure it's quite Al Pacino style but it seems like it's getting pretty close.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, it could be close, but the Indiana - - the lawyers for the Indiana State Treasurer Richard Murdock are going to be arguing on behalf of 100,000 Indiana pensioners, police officers as well as teachers that the sale to Fiat violates all kinds of bankruptcy law as well as the TARP law -- the law which created the Trouble Asset Relief Program. That's the argument they're going to make in court.

First, that senior secured lenders like the pensioners are being given a secondary position in this bankruptcy which is counter to Bankruptcy Law. Second, that the TARP was originally created to help financial institutions not automobile companies and that's a violation of the Troubled Asset Relief Program that was set up last year.

And that third, this is just a deal that is not good for the U.S. taxpayers. That's the argument they're going to make in court. And that argument lost. They didn't gain any ground with that argument when they presented it to Judge Arthur Gonzalez at the Bankruptcy Court.

They've also argued that this was a private plan agreed to before, they called it a Sub-Rosa plan, before Chrysler filed for bankruptcy, but again, Arthur Gonzalez said no that's just not the case. That's what the Appellate panel is going to hear; the three judges on the Appellate Court.

They're also going to be considering Chrysler's motion to certify the sale. If that happens, if the Indiana pensioners lose and Chrysler wins and the sale is certified, you can expect that sale to close almost immediately because Chrysler says it has to close the deal with Fiat by the 15th of June or else Fiat has the option to walk away from the table and worse it walks away with $35 million from Chrysler as a penalty for failing to close the deal.

So there's a lot riding on this decision today, Alexis.

One other thing in regards to that Hummer sale and the report that the Chinese are making perhaps a problem as to closing that deal because Hummers aren't fuel efficient. Hummer dealers will tell you that the H-3 which is the smaller Hummer -- it's built on the Chevy Colorado platform -- they'll tell you it gets better gas mileage on the highway than some of the import SUVs like the Lexus. So that's an argument that they are probably ready to fight.

Back to you.

GLICK: All right, Adam. I was just going to ask you about that, I appreciate it. All right, we'll check in with you a little later outside the court.

All right, well Chrysler is fighting two courtroom battles which Adam just talked about in its push to exit bankruptcy and merge with Fiat. In addition to today's hearing with the group of those Indiana state pensions and investment funds that are looking to block the deal. Close to 800 of the Chrysler's dealers are making their case in court. They made it yesterday to put the breaks on the plan.

For a closer look at the impact of the courtroom battles, Laurie Moncrieff is the president of Schmald Tool & Die, an auto parts supplier that did business for Chrysler, and joining us on the phone Jim Anderer, the owner of Island Jeep in Long Island who is fighting in court to keep his business open.

Laurie, don't worry about the people behind you. I saw you telling people to keep quiet. Believe me I do that every single day. All right Laurie, tell me first of all, what does this delay mean to you and your business?

LAURIE MONCRIEFF, PRESIDENT, SCHMALD TOOL & DIE: The manufacturers have been feeling the effects of what's been happening in the auto industry for quite some time. So quite frankly we're ready to get on with business.

The markets up here have been largely frozen because of what's going on in our economy in Michigan with the Detroit three. So in our opinion, we feel that moving forward quickly with the bankruptcy would be a help to the manufacturers.

GLICK: And Laurie, explain specifically what it is that you guys do and sort of where you fit into the food chain here in terms of how this impacts your business.

MONCRIEFF: We do precision machining and make dyes for the auto industry as well as many other industries. And quite frankly, all this upheaval is affecting a lot of industries besides just the auto industry.

GLICK: Great point.

Jim, I know you're joining us by phone. You've been kind enough to be here on several occasions. You're fighting to keep your dealership alive. You are one of those who received a pink slip. Tell me why the delay of this judgment of this decision could actually help you.

JIM ANDERER, PRESIDENT, ISLAND JEEP (via telephone): Hi, Alexis. Well, thanks for having me.

The delay helps me only in regard that it can possibly nix this deal. This is a bad deal for the American taxpayer. It's a bad deal for pretty much everybody involved, in my opinion.

I know that the vendor on the other line, you know, has her own agenda, and I'm sympathetic to that. But in my personal opinion this is a tragedy that's taking place in the American marketplace. It's putting 100,000 people out of work. It's really devastating to our economy right now. And I would like to see it nixed to be honest with you. I don't think it's a good deal...

GLICK: Ok, so Jim...

ANDERER: I think that Fiat is coming into this deal with no cash. And it's wrought with a lot of problems.

GLICK: Jim, you and I have talked about this before, and you have been in the courtroom. In fact you were in the courtroom yesterday speaking on behalf of those dealers who are being forced to shut down.

What convinces you that if the deal were not to go through with Fiat, that a liquidation of Chrysler would put you in a better position than if this deal were to go through?

ANDERER: Very simply that the market forces that would take place is exactly what should take place. The market forces would seek their own level which is the way it should be.

Ok, what's going on with this taxpayer bailout and all this other stuff? I mean, you know, give me a break. If -- whatever these particular brands are worth when they're in liquidation would be sold for what they are worth.

Ok I'm a stand-alone Jeep store. Jeep is never going to go away. It is going to be picked up by somebody. And whoever that is, is going to make a real go of it. But there's a false propping up of these brands is insanity. This is just not the way things should be done in a free marketplace.

GLICK: Laurie, let me switch to you for a moment. You actually feel that if they can make it through bankruptcy, that as suppliers, your position will be that much safer and more secure. Explain to people why that is.

LAURIE MONCRIEFF, PRESIDENT, SCHMALD TOOL & DIE: Well, it's always a lot more risky to do business with a company prior to bankruptcy than after bankruptcy so we felt a huge disruption, and quite frankly in the tool and die industry, we felt a huge disruption for many, many years and we've seen this coming for many years.

We've known there's been instability in the market for many years. We were somewhat of the canary in the mines frankly in this economy and have been discussing the problems in tooling and in manufacturing since the early 2000 because we could feel that it was very unstable, and that the economy was not doing well quite frankly in the early 2002, 2003.

There were a lot of discussions about the problems in the market. So while many of the dealers and other segments of the auto industry quite frankly probably weren't even aware of the problems we were very much aware of it in our industry.

GLICK: So Laurie when you look at the current environment, I mean look, you live in Flint, Michigan. We're actually going to talk to Virg Bernero a little bit later on this morning.

What are people doing right now to either make sure that companies like you are diversifying your risk or finding other viable job opportunities because I imagine everything is tightened up in Michigan?

MONCRIEFF: Everything's not only tightened up. It's frozen in the market right now. And it's not just the auto industry, it's the financial markets are really playing a huge role. The state of Michigan has been basically red lined by a lot of banks so lines of credit are being pulled, very much a big problem with getting financing to operate your business.

And then even in other industries when you diversify, we're feeling a lot of difficulty in a lot of other industries that are not even part of the auto industry because the financial market up in Michigan is frozen, as I said. So we're very anxious for the market to be unfrozen, whatever it takes to do that.

We need financing. We need money to start flowing to survive. That's basically what we're doing up here in Flint is working very, very hard to survive this right now.

GLICK: All right. Well, Laurie, we wish you the very best. And Jim, you too. Thank you guys so much for taking the time to join us this morning.

ANDERER: Thanks, Alexis.

MONCRIEFF: Thank you.

GLICK: Coming up, Countrywide's cofounder Angelo Mozilo charged with fraud by the SEC. The Judge is going to join us with his take.

And later the Palm Pre hits stores tomorrow. Will it take a bite out of Apple's iPhone? There's a lot of buzz about this. We're going to tell you about it in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: In court now, two executives from a defunct Seattle investment management firm are charged with running what prosecutors call one of the largest tax fraud schemes ever uncovered in the country. Quellos founder, Matthew Krane and CEO Jeffrey Greenstein and two others are charged with fraud, tax evasion and money laundering. Prosecutors say they created more than $1.3 billion in fraudulent losses for clients. Quellos used to be one of the world's biggest managers of mutual funds.

A jury not a judge will hear claims in a case between American International Group, AIG and Star International, the company controlled by Maurice Greenberg AIG's former CEO. The trial will now start June 15th. There are several lawsuits outstanding between AIG and Mr. Greenberg and sure wants Star to return AIG stocks and proceeds from stock sales. AIG received billions of dollars in federal bailout funds.

And the Securities and Exchange Commission charges former Countrywide CEO Angelo Mozilo with fraud and insider trading. Prosecutors say Mozilo and two other former executives misled investors about risky lending practices. The SEC also says Mozilo unloaded $140 million in Countrywide stock using insider information. It is the first case against a high-profile executive stemming from the sub prime mortgage meltdown. Mozilo has denied any wrongdoing and his lawyer calls the SEC's allegations baseless.

Our fox news senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano joins us right now for a look at the case. The judge is in the house and he's going to give us some explanations here. Judge, good to see you.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Good morning Alexis. Good to see you.

GLICK: surprised by this announcement?

NAPOLITANO: I'm surprised by this announcement. I expected -- and that would be standard operating procedure in a case like this -- an indictment rather than a civil lawsuit. This is a civil lawsuit the Securities and Exchange Commission says you didn't tell your opinion of your own products to your shareholders, and that caused them to acquire shares ignorant of what you thought of the products.

What did he think of them? Well the SEC got some e-mails, and in that he referred to his own products as toxic and poison. Now, that's the bad news that he said that in these e-mails. The good news for him is he was not indicted. He was not charged with a crime. The feds may still be investigating for that purpose.

But standard operating procedure in cases of fraud and insider trading is to indict and convict first and then to sue civilly. So the fact that they are suing him civilly, they are just looking for money and an order from a judge that he can never run a public company again. They are not looking to take away his freedom, tells me they don't have enough evidence to indict him or convict him.

GLICK: It's interesting because involved in this case also being charged with this as well is his chief operating officer and the CFO. All three of which are saying that number one, it's baseless. That they did divulge the proper information throughout the entire reporting process, and they say look the fact of the matter is the SEC has not done anything right in years, and they are using them as the poster child for what the SEC should have done over the past five years.

NAPOLITANO: Well, the SEC's failures is a political argument that the court will not allow them to make to a jury. But the court will let them say this, "Look, you have accused us of failing to share our opinions with everyone. You haven't us accused of failing to share facts."

This is not Enron or WorldCom where inaccurate data was given out. This is just a case where an opinion like toxic and poison wasn't shared with the public.

GLICK: Ok, but what is the chance, though, that when you read what the SEC is suggesting here, that this is brought on to suggest that it is very much like an Enron case, where they were not divulging material public information that could have affected decisions of shareholders, investors, etc.?

NAPOLITANO: It is a question of law for the court to decide. Is it material information what the CEO's personal opinion is of his products? These are not facts now. They didn't hide numbers. They didn't cook books. They just held back these words like toxic and poison.

Flip side of this is, if this was really insider trading, they would have indicted him. But because they haven't indicted him, what it is, is using insider knowledge to sell; knowledge that anyone else could have gotten had they looked into the books.

GLICK: Let's bring up one of those e-mails dating back to 2006 because I want people to hear specifically what he said. "In all my years in the business, I have never seen a more toxic product." That was one e-mail.

And since December of 2007, there have been 1.8 million jobs lost because of manufacturing. That accounts for three-tenths of all jobs lost since there. Construction employment down 59,000. And believe it or not, that's about half the average of the previous six months.

Household wages averaging $18.54. That is up .1 percent, year over year up 3.1 percent.

Also, government was up 92,000 last month. It was originally thought to be up 72,000 -- excuse me, that's for the month of April. The month of April up 92,000, originally thought to be 72,000.

Alexis, we'll leave it there. Back to you.

GLICK: All right. So, before I let you go, Rich, just to review this here right now, the 14.5 million people that are unemployed is the highest on which record? From what date?

EDSON: That was when record keeping began back in 1948. So it's the highest ever taken when they started all the way back in 1948.

GLICK: All right, terrific. And just before I let you go, any revisions? No revisions to unemployment rate, revisions downward for April and March in terms of non-farm payrolls?

EDSON: That's right. We lost fewer jobs in April and March. Originally, it was thought in April that we'd lost 539,000 jobs. That's now been revised to 504,000 jobs, so a difference of 35,000 jobs on the good side.

March, originally thought to be nearly 700,000, 699,000, we are now at 652,000 for the month of March. That is a change to the good side of 47,000.

GLICK: All right. Rich Edison, what a surprise. Thank you very much.

Let's break down the numbers.

Democratic Congressman Joe Sestak of Pennsylvania is with us; Roger Ballou, the president and CEO of the professional service company CDI; and John Lonski, chief economist for Moody's Investor Services.

Gentlemen, I'm in a little bit of shock, a little surprised.

John, let me start with you. You're my resident economist here.

Why would the unemployment rate tick up from 8.9 percent to 9.4 percent and yet in non-farm payrolls we lost a little less than 350,000?

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S INVESTOR SERVICES: Well, you know, we first have to consider that these job estimates are taken from two separate different surveys. The unemployment rate is taken from a household survey. The count of jobs, number of jobs is taken from a survey of employers.

That being said, you know, one of the defining characteristics of this recession has been the record length of unemployment. So while fewer people are losing their jobs -- and we pick that up from the recent decline if first time jobless claims -- we still find that the number of people that are out of work or collecting state unemployment benefits continues to grow. This is a recession where it was very damaging to have lost your job because of the unusually long period of time it's taken to secure new employment if you are that lucky.

GLICK: All right.

Let me go to Congressman Sestak.

Are you surprised by the numbers?

REP. JOE SESTAK (D), PENNSYLVANIA: Actually, I am. I had expected them to be in the low 500,000s. In fact, when we ran the models several months ago, if we had gotten to the low 500,000s or just below it by July, we would have assumed everything was going according to script -- still intense, but not intensifying. What this data shows is that as compared to past recessions, employers laid off employees much more rapidly when you look at the data, which means that this stopping of the cratering of our economy may come to a halt a bit more rapidly.

I had expected unemployment to be about 9.2 percent. And he is right, overall, people who don't have any jobs and aren't seeking is about 16 percent. But think about what else is now happening.

The yields in the financial market have really come down. We also see that the housing market is beginning to see the bottom of housing prices falling. We also are seeing here that consumer spending is actually beginning to increase as the rebates come back.

In fact, if you compare May of this year, when our rebates came out from the stimulus bill, to a year ago, it's hard to compare, because remember, Alexis, a year ago in May, we also had a stimulus bill. But when you see the two, comparison, it appears as though consumer confidence is beginning to come back. We'll get to about 10 percent unemployment by the end of the year, but I don't think we're going to go above it, and then we're out of here, as Mr. Bernanke pointed out recently, and our economy begins to go again.

GLICK: You know, Roger, you are an outsourcing firm. You deal with part- time and full-time workforce. Have you been seeing improving trends, or is this data a surprise to you?

ROGER BALLOU, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CDI: Actually, this data is confirmatory of what we have been seeing throughout our business, our MRINetwork offices across he country and our CDI professional staffing organizations, where, if you look at it, there have been a lot of bright areas in the economy in spite of the losses of jobs.

For example, rural economies have continued to perform better than urban economies, where they are driven by more commodities, agriculture, things like that. Secondly, the service sector, if you look at health care, has actually been experiencing growth through this.

We saw what appeared to be the beginning of the end of the recession at the end of the first quarter in our numbers. We saw it confirmed in April. We see it confirmed again here in May.

So what we're seeing in this national data is confirmation of what our MRINetwork offices and our professional organizations that we serve have been seeing over the last two or three months. So the actual exact number I couldn't have predicted, but we did predict that it was beginning of the end of the recession occurring in this last part of the first quarter, first part of the second quarter.

GLICK: Gentlemen, I want to bring up for just a moment what the market is doing in reaction to this, because the market is reacting pretty favorably -- that would be putting it lightly -- to this news.

The market was up about 40 beforehand. The Dow now up 135 points. So we're up 1.5 percent. The S&P right now is up 1.7 percent and Nasdaq up a percent. So we've rallied a full one percent in reaction to this.

Two points.

Congressman Sestak, let me first start with you on the president's fiscal stimulus package. He has tried to demonstrate in several speeches recently that the fiscal stimulus is starting to work its way into the economy. Money is being spent. I think he recently said about 100,000 jobs have been saved or created.

Is this proof in the pudding that in fact it is starting to work, and it was the necessary fuel that we needed to get everybody off the sidelines?

SESTAK: Yes, I believe it was one of the necessary tools. We also have to give a lot of credit to the TARP program and the TALF program, the second one, as you well know, to the Federal Reserve, because they have gotten the mother milk of our economy, credit, flowing again. And so there's a lot more confidence in the markets also.

But without a doubt, this economic stimulus bill intended to get money out there so people would spend it. A lot of it on retailing has started to work. Now what you are going to see is later this year, the construction money -- only about six percent of it has been spent thus far -- is really going to kick in just as the recession seems to be coming to a halt and is ready to come up. I think it's been well played.

GLICK: You know, John, it's interesting. I was speaking to Jim Rohr, the chairman and CEO of PNC, and the other day he said, "Alexis, one of the greatest stimulus in this economy has been what the Fed has done because those who have been able to refinance on average has saved about $300 on monthly payments."

I wonder, is that stimulus generated by refi activity enough to offset the fact that as we sit here right now, oil is breaking above $70 a barrel, it's at a seven-month high, and so what was perceived as a tax credit because of declining gasoline and oil prices is now going to be a tax on consumers?

LONSKI: You know, we have to keep our eye on energy prices, but I believe that when consumers look at energy prices, they take a longer-term view. And they didn't believe that oil was going to stay at $40 to $50 per gallon.

Consumer spending proceeds on the assumption the price of crude oil will be in a range of $60 to $70 per barrel. So we are hitting the upper end of this range beyond which consumer spending might indeed suffer. And so it would behoove the administration to take any action necessary to prevent a replay of what happened in the first half of 2008, when the price of crude oil soared up to nearly $150 per barrel. If that happens again, then the wait for the next economic recovery will be longer than we currently anticipate.

GLICK: Yes.

I mean, Roger, there's a lot of confluences of events right now that are beginning to signal that perhaps the global economy is starting to heal. The concern is -- and John brings up some great points -- is that inflation, things of that nature become a bigger concern and act as a tax on consumers or cause interest rates to rise.

What impact, if any, will all this have on the corporations that you talk to on a daily basis who are looking to slowly but surely begin to bring new employees into the fold?

BALLOU: Well, I think two things.

Congressman Sestak commented earlier that -- I think what you saw this time is a steeper quicker reduction in employment and inventories than we have ever seen before. I think that the information systems companies now used to control their inventories and their production capacity led them to react much, much more quickly. What I think that's going to lead to is a slower sustained recovery coming out of this, so it's going to be like a reverse hockey stick, where you saw a quicker downtick, but a gradual uptick that will come.

I also agree that I think the financial programs are the key driver of the uptick here. I don't think that much of the stimulus has kicked in yet, so I suspect that the bigger stimulus effect here has been the credit markets opening up, and that leading to enhanced consumer confidence and business confidence.

The other thing that's gone on is the global economy, where you see the Indian economy continuing to grow very, very strongly. You see the Chinese economy in resurgence based on their stimulus programs. So I think those things are contributing significantly to the uptick as well.

So, it is an interconnected global economy. In our case, I think the financial programs have been very, very critical to it. I also think the president himself has been instilling confidence through his communication, through his demeanor, through the programs that he's launched. And this is a very -- you know, people's psyches are fragile, but they also can move in a positive direction, very, very quickly, and I think you are beginning to see that occurring.

GLICK: Congressman Sestak, I'm going to give you the last word.

One of the things about the data shows that number of hours worked have dropped. Productivity, as we just saw yesterday, is rising.

One material concern out there is that we will see declining wages, that we've seen declining wages, but that it will be a bigger issue that the consumer will still remain fairly tapped out. And because we've figured out how to accomplish more with less workers, that some of those jobs may not come back.

How important is it to find those future jobs that will perhaps replace a lot of the millions of jobs of the six million that we have seen since the recession began?

SESTAK: This is an excellent point you make.

We have lost about a trillion dollars in our GDP as compared to our 2007 GDP high peak. And if we just have an economy, as was just mentioned, that grows slowly, and let's just say it grows at 2.5 percent, which was the average between 2001 and 2007, it will take us three years to soak up that $1 trillion of lost GDP capacity. Which means if we don't grow more rapidly, we won't be creating these jobs that you spoke about.

That's why the president's budget is absolutely critical. If he is -- and I believe he is -- intent upon in succeeding in retooling the economy in the types of jobs, the green energy jobs, the ability to reform our health care system, those parts of this budget will be absolutely critical.

Second, I go back that we have to do more in the entrepreneur incentives by the right tax incentives to get that extra bump to our economy above 2.5 percent growth in the next few years to come, or we won't create those jobs.

GLICK: Right. Good point.

SESTAK: Because China is growing this year 6.8 percent as we lose about five or six percent. So that's why this is important, your point.

GLICK: All right, guys. We are going to leave it there. Terrific, terrific discussion.

I'm glad to see we've seen some relief in the numbers, but remember still a lot of people unemployed in this economy.

Congressman Sestak, Roger and John, thank you so much, gentlemen.

SESTAK: Thank you for having me.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you.

GLICK: A reminder, by the way please join me, 9:35 a.m. Eastern Time. I will be speaking to the labor secretary, Hilda Solis, in a "First on Fox" interview here to break down this May employment number. So please tune in for that. We'll get an opportunity to get her thoughts in just about 45 minutes.

All right. Coming up, more jobs lost. We're talking to students just entering the working world about their hunt for employment.

And of course we will head live to the New York Stock Exchange for a little bit of a preview on what is now a market that's looking pretty good.

We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All week we have been taking a look at the nation's growing deficit as a result of government spending as something we called red ink. Now, MONEY FOR BREAKFAST teamed up with the college news service U-Wire to take a closer look at Generation Debt, the students of America who will inherit the current deficit

Some of those students told us the financial worries that are keeping them -- frankly, they're keeping them up at night. Take a listen to what they had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My biggest financial concern is just to find a job after I graduate.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm more worried about people my parents' age who have just seen their retirement funds completely be gone.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My parents' businesses since December, like, their sales have been halved. And that kind of really affects me because I'm in school now. I can't help them out.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My personal biggest financial concern is just being able to live the life that we're expected to live as -- you know, again since I came from a background where my parents didn't necessarily have a lot of money, I think there was a big expectation for me coming to college and getting the job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GLICK: Well, as you heard, some of the students we spoke to say finding a job is their top worry. With roughly 1.5 million graduating seniors entering the workforce this year and a loss of another 500,000 -- well, now actually we have seen 350,000 jobs in May, according to the most recent survey -- what will they do? And is now the time to figure out other options?

Joining us right now, Emily Sutherland, who is heading into her senior year at Colorado State; Leah Finnegan, who graduated from the University of Texas this year; and Dean Van Tassell, who received his MBA from Pace University just two weeks ago.

Good morning, guys. Good to see you.

LEAH FINNEGAN, UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS GRADUATE: Good morning.

DEAN VAN TASSELL, RECEIVED MBA FROM PACE UNIVERSITY: Good morning.

EMILY SUTHERLAND, HEADING INTO SENIOR YEAR AT COLORADO STATE: Good morning.

GLICK: All right, Dean. Let me talk to you.

You just graduated two weeks ago from Pace University. You have been on the job hunt. What have you been experiencing?

VAN TASSELL: Well, first of all, thank you for having me on the program. And BB&T Capital Markets loves Fox Business.

GLICK: Oh, that's good to know. Thanks.

VAN TASSELL: I have been applying to, let's see now, about 70 different investment banks, writing the HR departments, following with managing directors, trying to get my name out there as much as possible. I have a nice stack of rejection letters right now, so it's rough out there.

You know, you have to start making contingency plans. And it's -- you know, we're up to 9.4 percent. The only solace I have is that maybe the 9.4 percent unemployment is backwards looking, and the market seems to be shrugging it off today. So hopefully we will have second derivative fever and things will start to level out and pick up relatively soon.

GLICK: Leah, you just graduated from the University of Texas. You have a BA in American studies.

What kind of jobs have you been looking for?

FINNEGAN: I'm actually going into journalism, which is, you know, quite an experience at this time. And I applied to about 20 jobs, and I heard "No" from about five. And then I just didn't hear from the rest of them. So it's kind of like applying to a black hole.

GLICK: Yes, radio silence.

So what did you decide to do when you just weren't getting back any responses or you were just getting rejection notes without even, as I understand, getting an opportunity to even interview?

FINNEGAN: Well, my contingency plan was grad school, and I wasn't sure if I wanted to go, and kind of applied on the lark and ended up getting into grad school and not getting into any jobs. So grad school it is.

GLICK: So you're going to Columbia?

FINNEGAN: Yes.

GLICK: My alma mater.

FINNEGAN: Oh, OK.

GLICK: Very excited. OK.

Now Emily, let me talk to you. I understand you are majoring in communications. You are going to be a senior this year at Colorado State.

When you listen to what's happening to Dean and Leah and I'm sure a lot of your other classmates, how is that impacting you? How nervous does it make you knowing that you are going into your senior year of college?

SUTHERLAND: Well, it makes me really nervous, of course. A lot of my friends have graduated. A lot of them have resulted in working at Starbucks and their degree has gotten them absolutely nowhere. So I just hope that things pick up so I actually do have job opportunities out there once I graduate.

GLICK: Dean, you smiled there. I mean, how many of your friends and colleagues have had to do that? Like, you might have had aspirations of working on Wall Street or working in a particular sector, but there's no opportunities and you have to get what you can get.

VAN TASSELL: I know a lot of people who would be lucky to get a job at Starbucks. It's hard.

I will probably have to go back to bartending for a little bit, but it seem just as competitive as Wall Street, if not more. You have a lot of people laid off and in the same position I'm in, so a lot of people just don't have any options, even contingency plans.

The number one thing I hear is there's a lot of government jobs out there, but the mentality of, I want to work on Wall Street, I'm very aggressive, I want to be in the financial markets than going into a government job, it's a bit different from what you have expected might be around after you graduate. So...

GLICK: Right.

And Leah, how many other classmates of yours have said they are going to choose to continue to go back to school because that's really the only and best option?

FINNEGAN: A really good number. It is a very popular option right now. And I don't know, I'm kind of finding the whole experience a bit freeing, and I think a lot of people my peers are as well, that now we have this time right now to kind of relax and discover what we really want to do.

GLICK: Good point.

FINNEGAN: and then we have the rest of our lives to do it. So there's not so much pressure to be successful and make more than $100,000 right out of college.

GLICK: Great point.

I wish you all the best success. Leah, Dean and Emily, thank you guys so much.

VAN TASSELL: Thank you.

FINNEGAN: Thank you.

SUTHERLAND: Thank you.

GLICK: All right, guys. We're going to take a break. We will be right back with "THE OPENING BELL" in just a moment. We're just about five minutes away.

All right. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Welcome back. It's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

Connell, you were watching actually the bond market reaction to the jobs data. What did you see happen?

MCSHANE: Well, a big move up in yields, which is really going to be the story that we're going to have to follow very, very closely, Alexis, when you think about it.

And Charles, you and I talked about this, the idea that hey, maybe the economy has bottomed out and things are starting to look better, but what about rising yields, rising mortgage rates, and other things? And does that cut off the recovery?

GLICK: It could be a tough bear market for the bonds.

PAYNE: Absolutely. And also, I was looking at equities. I thought the Dow and this type of number would be up 200, 300 points. I'm serious. I think we have a conflict here with the unemployment number being 9.4.

GLICK: I agree.

PAYNE: Two separate surveys -- the Household Survey saying, listen, it's tough, it's tougher than the way the businesses maybe are looking at it.

GLICK: Yes. You've got to wonder why the divergence.

And speaking of which, actually, I'm going to talk to Labor Secretary Hilda Solis coming up on "THE OPENING BELL," 9:35 a.m. Eastern Time. So tune in. She will he' be joining us "First on Fox."

All right, guys. We'll be right back.

END

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST, breaking news, the "Wall Street Journal" reporting General Motors inked a preliminary deal to sell its Saturn division to mega auto dealer Roger Penske -- details ahead.

And could a shakeup be coming at Citigroup? The Journal reporting Sheila Bair and the FDIC want a change and it could include CEO Vikram Pandit. Who might be tapped to replace him? And what do the people at Citigroup think?

And the SEC charges Mozilo federal regulators charge Countrywide cofounder Angelo Mozilo with insider trading and securities fraud. What will happen to him next?

We're serving these stories and much more this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

Good morning and happy Friday. Welcome to MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. I'm Alexis Glick.

Coming up this morning, much more on the latest on GM Saturn sale and that possible shakeup at Citigroup.

Some of those students told us the financial worries that are keeping them -- frankly, they're keeping them up at night. Take a listen to what they had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My biggest financial concern is just to find a job after I graduate.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm more worried about people my parents' age who have just seen their retirement funds completely be gone.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My parents' businesses since December, like, their sales have been halved. And that kind of really affects me because I'm in school now. I can't help them out.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My personal biggest financial concern is just being able to live the life that we're expected to live as -- you know, again since I came from a background where my parents didn't necessarily have a lot of money, I think there was a big expectation for me coming to college and getting the job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GLICK: Well, as you heard, some of the students we spoke to say finding a job is their top worry. With roughly 1.5 million graduating seniors entering the workforce this year and a loss of another 500,000 -- well, now actually we have seen 350,000 jobs in May, according to the most recent survey -- what will they do? And is now the time to figure out other options?

Joining us right now, Emily Sutherland, who is heading into her senior year at Colorado State; Leah Finnegan, who graduated from the University of Texas this year; and Dean Van Tassell, who received his MBA from Pace University just two weeks ago.

Good morning, guys. Good to see you.

LEAH FINNEGAN, UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS GRADUATE: Good morning.

DEAN VAN TASSELL, RECEIVED MBA FROM PACE UNIVERSITY: Good morning.

EMILY SUTHERLAND, HEADING INTO SENIOR YEAR AT COLORADO STATE: Good morning.

GLICK: All right, Dean. Let me talk to you.

You just graduated two weeks ago from Pace University. You have been on the job hunt. What have you been experiencing?

VAN TASSELL: Well, first of all, thank you for having me on the program. And BB&T Capital Markets loves Fox Business.

GLICK: Oh, that's good to know. Thanks.

VAN TASSELL: I have been applying to, let's see now, about 70 different investment banks, writing the HR departments, following with managing directors, trying to get my name out there as much as possible. I have a nice stack of rejection letters right now, so it's rough out there.

You know, you have to start making contingency plans. And it's -- you know, we're up to 9.4 percent. The only solace I have is that maybe the 9.4 percent unemployment is backwards looking, and the market seems to be shrugging it off today. So hopefully we will have second derivative fever and things will start to level out and pick up relatively soon.

GLICK: Leah, you just graduated from the University of Texas. You have a BA in American studies.

What kind of jobs have you been looking for?

FINNEGAN: I'm actually going into journalism, which is, you know, quite an experience at this time. And I applied to about 20 jobs, and I heard "No" from about five. And then I just didn't hear from the rest of them. So it's kind of like applying to a black hole.

GLICK: Yes, radio silence.

So what did you decide to do when you just weren't getting back any responses or you were just getting rejection notes without even, as I understand, getting an opportunity to even interview?

FINNEGAN: Well, my contingency plan was grad school, and I wasn't sure if I wanted to go, and kind of applied on the lark and ended up getting into grad school and not getting into any jobs. So grad school it is.

GLICK: So you're going to Columbia?

FINNEGAN: Yes.

GLICK: My alma mater.

FINNEGAN: Oh, OK.

GLICK: Very excited. OK.

Now Emily, let me talk to you. I understand you are majoring in communications. You are going to be a senior this year at Colorado State.

When you listen to what's happening to Dean and Leah and I'm sure a lot of your other classmates, how is that impacting you? How nervous does it make you knowing that you are going into your senior year of college?

SUTHERLAND: Well, it makes me really nervous, of course. A lot of my friends have graduated. A lot of them have resulted in working at Starbucks and their degree has gotten them absolutely nowhere. So I just hope that things pick up so I actually do have job opportunities out there once I graduate.

GLICK: Dean, you smiled there. I mean, how many of your friends and colleagues have had to do that? Like, you might have had aspirations of working on Wall Street or working in a particular sector, but there's no opportunities and you have to get what you can get.

VAN TASSELL: I know a lot of people who would be lucky to get a job at Starbucks. It's hard.

I will probably have to go back to bartending for a little bit, but it seem just as competitive as Wall Street, if not more. You have a lot of people laid off and in the same position I'm in, so a lot of people just don't have any options, even contingency plans.

The number one thing I hear is there's a lot of government jobs out there, but the mentality of, I want to work on Wall Street, I'm very aggressive, I want to be in the financial markets than going into a government job, it's a bit different from what you have expected might be around after you graduate. So...

GLICK: Right.

And Leah, how many other classmates of yours have said they are going to choose to continue to go back to school because that's really the only and best option?

FINNEGAN: A really good number. It is a very popular option right now. And I don't know, I'm kind of finding the whole experience a bit freeing, and I think a lot of people my peers are as well, that now we have this time right now to kind of relax and discover what we really want to do.

GLICK: Good point.

FINNEGAN: and then we have the rest of our lives to do it. So there's not so much pressure to be successful and make more than $100,000 right out of college.

GLICK: Great point.

I wish you all the best success. Leah, Dean and Emily, thank you guys so much.

VAN TASSELL: Thank you.

FINNEGAN: Thank you.

SUTHERLAND: Thank you.

GLICK: All right, guys. We're going to take a break. We will be right back with "THE OPENING BELL" in just a moment. We're just about five minutes away.

All right. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Welcome back. It's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

Connell, you were watching actually the bond market reaction to the jobs data. What did you see happen?

MCSHANE: Well, a big move up in yields, which is really going to be the story that we're going to have to follow very, very closely, Alexis, when you think about it.

And Charles, you and I talked about this, the idea that hey, maybe the economy has bottomed out and things are starting to look better, but what about rising yields, rising mortgage rates, and other things? And does that cut off the recovery?

GLICK: It could be a tough bear market for the bonds.

PAYNE: Absolutely. And also, I was looking at equities. I thought the Dow and this type of number would be up 200, 300 points. I'm serious. I think we have a conflict here with the unemployment number being 9.4.

GLICK: I agree.

PAYNE: Two separate surveys -- the Household Survey saying, listen, it's tough, it's tougher than the way the businesses maybe are looking at it.

GLICK: Yes. You've got to wonder why the divergence.

And speaking of which, actually, I'm going to talk to Labor Secretary Hilda Solis coming up on "THE OPENING BELL," 9:35 a.m. Eastern Time. So tune in. She will he' be joining us "First on Fox."

All right, guys. We'll be right back.

END

urn:contentItem:5XB3-SGT1-DY07-D003-00000-00Chubb Chief Digital Officer Ringsted Sounds Off on Innovation, ITC and the Future2019-10-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisChubb Chief Digital Officer Ringsted Sounds Off on Innovation, ITC and the Future

Sean Ringsted was one of the 7,000 or so people who attended the 2019 InsureTech Connect Conference, held Sept. 23 to 25 in Las Vegas.

Ringsted is executive vice president, chief digital officer and chief risk officer at Chubb Group, and he visited ITC in part, to nurture existing business contacts and make new ones.

Sean Ringsted/Chubb

InsureTech Connect is arguably the biggest network event around for InsurTechs and carriers seeking to form partnerships or other business arrangements, and Ringsted took advantage of that, describing the convention as "an intense few days of meetings" between the Chubb team with both existing and potential new InsurTech partners.

Below, as part of a Q&A withCarrier ManagementEditor Mark Hollmer, Ringsted elaborates on what he and Chubb gained from the massive networking event. He also offered a primer on Chubb's InsurTech perspectives, strategy and progress.

Q: How was this year's ITC event?

Ringsted: The event was excellent. The agenda covered the use of technology by every corner of the insurance industry and provided the opportunity for an intense few days of meetings by the Chubb team with existing and potential InsurTech partners. This was helped by a record attendance, ranging from small startups to Big Tech such as Microsoft and Google. This year, there was also a greater emphasis on using technology to improve the customer experience.

Q: What did you learn from it?

Ringsted: As expected, there was a great deal of focus on technology and innovation at ITC, and the industry's use of the latest capabilities in AI, data analytics, machine learning, robotics, IoT, etc. Listening to the discussions and the potential for tech-driven change, I believe we are all still working with the same core set of insurance business principles that have stood the test of time, namely disciplined underwriting and keeping our promise to pay claims. Technology is helping to make welcome changes in the customer experience, including the ability to buy and service their policies as well as assist insurers with their decision-making and operations. However, we need to remain focused on our fundamentals and not lose sight of the importance of the human touch with our customers, especially in time of need. I saw a greater recognition of the need for this balance between tech and the human touch at this year's ITC .

Q: Why were you there?

Ringsted: For Chubb, ITC offers a great opportunity to network, deepen existing relationships with partners and vendors, explore new partnership opportunities, understand the competitive landscape and learn about new market and technology trends. Aside from the structured sessions and meetings, I found equally valuable the corridor discussions and introductions that would otherwise take months to replicate. I also really enjoy setting aside time to meet with the "grassroots" InsurTechs, which always provides a fresh and energetic view on the underlying pulse of the entrepreneurs.

Q: How goes Chubb's innovation evolution?

Ringsted: We have a clear strategy to lead and thrive in the Digital Age and continue to execute on those objectives. Our efforts are in three areas-doing the simple things smarter in our operations, the use of data analytics to improve claims and underwriting decision making and digitizing our product, services and the overall customer experience.

We are becoming an increasingly digitally integrated organization by investing $1 billion annually on new innovation and improving legacy technology to provide anytime, anywhere access and processing, as well as new front-end capabilities including improved customer experience and an expanding ecosystem of digital distribution partners. Chubb's global scale provides us access to new markets, ideas and capabilities which is allowing us to sign major distribution partnership agreements, digitally enhance the customer experience and reimagine our product offering.

Q: Where do you see the InsurTech innovation landscape in five years?

Ringsted: InsurTech is here to stay. Today we are focused on what is most visible right in front of us, such as improving the customer experience on the front end and better use of data analytics to improve decision making and operational effectiveness. The industry of tomorrow will need to meet a growing demand for new products and services. Insurance will need new products to help address secular challenges such as healthcare, ageing, urbanization, and climate change. New industries are emerging with new insurance needs such as the gig economy, mobility and shared workspaces. InsurTech will provide collaboration opportunities and competition, both welcome, for the industry as it solves its old challenges and rises to meet the new.

Q: What's the easiest thing for carriers seeking to incorporate innovation into their routines?

Ringsted: It's important to have clarity and a sense of business purpose. Innovation spawned in a vacuum will have a harder chance to succeed and provide true business impact. Not every bet will succeed and that it is about learning fast (not failing fast) and adapting quickly.

Q: What's the biggest challenge for carriers seeking to incorporate innovation into their routines?

Ringsted: Building solutions for each partner can be time, resource and cost intensive. Patience is required.

In our plans, we factor in the time spent with partners, negotiating with vendors and contractually agreeing to intellectual property rights, data ownership, handling of breaches, etc. to stand up new digital products and services. Issues are not new nor are they a result of innovation occurring in the insurance space. Existing laws and regulations on insurance product and also around privacy, IP, data protection, data localization, etc. must be complied with regardless of the technology or platform utilized.

A trustworthy, longstanding carrier brand like Chubb underscores the importance of the "last mile" execution to ensure that quality, trust and security are incorporated into the innovation collaboration with InsurTech.

Q: Are carriers keeping up with InsurTech changes?

Ringsted: Speaking from a Chubb perspective, I believe we are keeping up. We retain a focus on our business objectives that allows us to filter through to the companies that can potentially provide material benefit to us.

Q: If carriers need to approach InsurTech innovation differently, what should they do?

Ringsted: The InsurTech industry is both vibrant and broad in terms of opportunity. Clearly there is a balance to be had-the "Goldilocks conundrum." Those companies that are not engaged with InsurTech are likely to be missing out. At the same time, those companies that are heavily engaged across the sector need to be sure that the effort matches the business benefit.

urn:contentItem:5R18-B0F1-JBCN-44FY-00000-00Chuck Muth: Franken’s frightening fix for free speech menace2017-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisOPINIONChuck Muth: Franken’s frightening fix for free speech menaceCHUCK MUTH

Comedian-turned-senator Al Franken – yes, that Al Franken—recently wrote an op-ed published in The Guardian titled, "We Must Not Let Big Tech Threaten Our Security, Freedoms and Democracy." Pretty frightening. Not for the alleged problems Franken outlines, but the "Big Brother" government remedies he proposes.

Franken warns of the "outsized role that the major tech companies" – primarily Google, Facebook and Twitter – "play in so many aspects of our lives." He goes on to accuse these companies of failing "to take commonsense precautions to prevent the spread of propaganda, misinformation, and hate speech."

Of course, by "commonsense precautions" Franken is really proposing government-sanctioned, if not imposed, censorship. And what Franken personally considers to be propaganda, misinformation and hate speech might very well not be considered such by others.

As the old saying goes, one man's trash is another man's treasure.

Indeed, in reading Franken's manifesto I came to conclusion that it, itself, is government propaganda by a government official that is filled with misinformation.

For example, Franken claims it's "alarming" that these three tech companies "have unprecedented power to guide Americans' access to information and potentially shape the future of journalism."

You mean like the unprecedented power ABC, NBC and CBS had on television before the advent of cable TV?

"(A)s the wealth of information available on the internet has grown," Franken wrote, "big tech has taken it upon itself to sort through all the viewpoints, news, and entertainment, and decide for us what we should read, watch, buy, or even how we should engage in civil society."

For decades the Big Three television networks took it upon themselves to sort through all the viewpoints, news, and entertainment and decide for us what we should watch.

But now, thanks to the very technology Franken seeks to regulate and censor, Americans have thousands upon thousands of options and alternatives which the people themselves sort through and determine for themselves what viewpoints, news and entertainment they choose to read, watch or listen to.

Why would anyone ever want the government to take that away from us?

In conclusion, Franken asks, "What role should these companies play in our lives?"

Wrong question. The real question is what role the GOVERNMENT should play in our lives.

Thank you very much, but I can decide for myself what role Google, Facebook and Twitter play in my life. And I have no interest whatsoever in returning to the Stone Age days when the Big Three TV networks decided what I should watch.

Mr. Franken is free to make suggestions and recommendations as to what I should read, watch, or listen to. But when it comes to him using the coercive power of government to make those decisions for me, I defer to those three famous words by former First Lady Nancy Reagan …

Just … say … no.

urn:contentItem:5WP8-24V1-JD34-V0G5-00000-00Churches wrong on abortion2019-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 21Churches wrong on abortion

Abortion legislation should be supported, not sabotaged, by churches ("MPs act to bring abortion reform closer", July 30).

The writing is on the wall but, as usual, the Australian Christian Lobby can't read it. After a traumatic journey, NSW legislation is about to catch up with the rest of Australia but it is tragic that the same tax-exempt organisations that opposed legislative change to treat vulnerable people better are,

once again, putting on the battle helmet instead of giving a

helping hand.

The Christian tradition has consistently arrived at the wrong conclusion when it places the words of a pre-Enlightenment document in the driving seat rather than the welfare of contemporary human beings .

Just as the marriage equality debate yesterday, abortion today and religious freedom tomorrow, an ethical navigation system that hasn't been updated for 2000 years will have us arriving at a series of stinking wheelie bins instead of positive community destinations.Father Peter Macleod-Miller,

St Matthew's, Albury

The bill supports health and reproductive rights but has no regard of the precious rights of the reproductive result.

Ronald Mackinnon, Elizabeth Bay

I appreciate Deborah Bateson's point in her opinion piece that things can be made easier for women, but I just can't see whether the same work is being done to make things easier for the even more needy child in the womb ("Abortion is healthcare, not a crime - and at last the law will catch up", July 29).

The article mentions women 10 times but children not once.

Simon Manchester, senior minister

St Thomas', North Sydney

PM's weasel words

It seemed a straightforward question in Parliament from the Greens to the Prime Minister regarding possible lobbying by his ministers for expedited visa processing for Chinese high rollers intending to visit the Crown casino ("Lack of Crown scrutiny shows lobbying pays off", July 30).

The PM's response was that "there has been nothing presented to me that would indicate there are any matters there for me to address".

Such weasel words are disrespectful and an abrogation of accountability to the Parliament.

Russ Couch, Woonona

It would seem our federal government had no qualms at all about facilitating visas for Chinese high rollers to accommodate Crown.

This is a federal government that can't accommodate a few hundred bona fide refugees languishing on Manus Island.

Mary Lawson, Marrickville

Religious dogma is poison

As the religious freedom debate rages, it clearly all boils down to the misguided belief that "my religion is better than yours" (Letters, July 30).

A timely reminder indeed of the late Christopher Hitchens immortal words: "Religion poisons everything."

Swap religious dogma for a liberal dose of love, compassion and common sense and the world would be a better place.

Joy Nason, Mona Vale

Rules of engagement

Your correspondent opines the UK is more likely to join a coalition with Australia in a war against Iran because Boris Johnson is now PM (Letters, July 30) .

Fortunately for the British, their parliament retains the exclusive right to authorise the UK going to war. Despite many in this country calling for our federal parliament to have the same rights, declarations of war by Australia may only be issued by the government of the day.

I expect a great many citizens are against joining coalitions in foreign wars, as we saw with protests against Australia's involvement in Iraq.

Australia adopting a neutral self-defence posture is an option little considered, as is the proposition that our elected representatives should hold at least a veto over going to war.

David Sargent, Castle Hill

At last, some good news

Every day we read about the failures of our governments, so how good is it that Peter Hartcher is able to write about some successes we have achieved in the areas of social media, tax avoidance and the market dominance of Big Tech companies ("Day of reckoning upon Big Tech", July 30).

The achievements are recognised and the departments involved encouraged to continue in their pursuits of providing appropriate regulation, while allowing innovation to flourish.

Peter Nash, Fairlight

PM lies to 'average' Aussies

Scott Morrison says that the Newstart allowance doesn't need to be increased because it's better to provide jobs for the unemployed ("Low-skilled migrants and lax employer laws 'driving down wages"', July 30).

But at the same time his government has sat for their six-plus years watching as hundreds of thousands of Australians and migrant workers have been underpaid and ripped off by unscrupulous employers.

So much for his election claims that his Coalition, not Labor, looks after average Australians and migrant workers. And so much for their belief in trickle-down economics that has only seen stagnant wages as a torrent of riches trickles up to the wealthy.

Kevin Farrell, Beelbangera

Saving hints for Barnaby

Here is a to-do list for Barnaby Joyce, now that he can empathise with those who are less fortunate owing to his dire financial circumstances (Letters, July 30).

Shopping; buy anything on special. Clothing will need to be bought at Vinnies, Salvos or Lifeline. Eating out will be confined to Maccas, and then if there is a little money left over, he can go to the local RSL and play the pokies in the hope he might get a win and pay for a few bills.

Janice Hull, Hat Head

More funds for recycling

Your correspondent makes a good point about the need to use alternative materials to make power poles (Letters, July 30). His wise words raise an even more profound point, especially considering the recent returns of plastic waste from Indonesia.

Why isn't Australia funding research into recycling generally? Surely there is much to be gained by being world leaders in this field. It may not be as glamorous as space travel, but it may do more to save the world.

Tom Orren, Wamberal Heights

urn:contentItem:5XH7-D691-F072-J48D-00000-00CIBC Global Technology fund manager discusses his vision for beating the market;The CIBC fund s average annual return of 19.8 per cent over the past three years outperformed all peers2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:25ZLexisNexisBUSINESSCIBC Global Technology fund manager discusses his vision for beating the marketThe CIBC fund s average annual return of 19.8 per cent over the past three years outperformed all peersTim ShufeltABSTRACT

The CIBC fund s average annual return of 19.8 per cent over the past three years outperformed all peers

FULL TEXT

When you're competing against some of the best tech investors in the world, getting in early is crucial, said Jonathan Mzengeza.

Take Shopify Inc. Over the three years or so Mr. Mzengeza has held the stock in the CIBC Global Technology fund, the company has gone from a peripheral e-commerce startup to one of the country's largest public companies, with the share price rising nearly tenfold.

And it's still early days for Shopify, Mr. Mzengeza said, suggesting he expects the holding to continue driving excess returns.

The CIBC Global Technology fund was recently recognized for industry-best performance by the Lipper Fund Awards, which ranks Canadian portfolio managers across several different categories.

In the global equity category, the CIBC fund's average annual return of 19.8 per cent over the past three years outperformed all peers. Mr. Mzengeza spoke to The Globe and Mail about how he goes about beating the market.

What is your approach with this fund?

We try to invest early in the lifecycle of secular themes. Right now we're looking at 5G, AI, machine learning, cloud, payments and e-commerce. And we try to find those names which are not as well followed.

Do you avoid the FAANG stocks?

We're staying away from Facebook and Alphabet, not just because of valuation, but because of regulatory risk around the business model.

Are you worried about another tech stock bubble?

The fundamental strength of these businesses is better than the last time around. They generate free cash flow, they generate profit, they're continuously growing. Valuations may be stretched, so we have allocated more towards health care, where there is more of a value tilt. And we've raised some cash that we can deploy if there is a sell-off.

Is Shopify's valuation stretched?

Right now, $183-billion of commerce goes through the Shopify platform. And their revenue is only $1.6-billion. Can they take a bigger share of that revenue base? I believe that they can. We're still at the very early stages of e-commerce penetration. As a good analogy, if you put $1,000 in Amazon when it IPO'd 25 years ago, that would be worth more than $1-million.

Amazon went public early on in its evolution. With startups staying private for longer, is it more challenging to tap into the earlier stages of a company's growth?

That has made it challenging. Some of the companies we would have wanted to invest in at an earlier stage, like Uber or Lyft, we haven't been able to do that. But we're still seeing plenty of early-stage companies. We've participated in a few IPOs this year, including Zoom Video Communications and PagerDuty. Both of those performed pretty well out of the gate. And we sold out when valuations became a bit stretched.

Any other Canadian names in the fund besides Shopify?

You have better opportunities outside Canada. If you're looking for a leading company within a sector, I struggle to find any other companies within Canada beyond Shopify.

The fund seems to have a heavy weighting in payment technology.

Fiserv and Global Payments are unique opportunities because of the fact that the payment industry is going through consolidation. Fiserv bought First Data and Global Payments bought TSYS and we think there's an opportunity for outsized synergies from both those acquisitions. As for Mastercard, we own it because of the fact they're moving from from cash and cheques to digital payments. And Mastercard has done a good job of outgrowing Visa.

How are you navigating the AI space?

We're in the phase when people are building up the infrastructure that's going to enable AI. If you think about this as a gold rush, we want to be with the people who are supplying the picks and axes and not the people who are actually getting the gold out of the ground. Our main investment in AI is Nvidia, which makes their GPUs available for AI and machine learning, and they're a leader in that segment.

Any other big tech themes you like right now?

We have a position in IAC, which owns about 80 per cent of Match. It's going to spin out that investment. And we think Match as an asset is undervalued. It owns the likes of Tinder, Hinge and a lot of other online dating websites. Another one is gaming. We hold Activision Blizzard, which owns the Overwatch League. Our other big investment in the space is Tencent, which is one of the biggest video game developers in the world. They own League of Legends and they own part of Epic Games, which owns Fortnite. The younger generation is more interested in spending their downtime playing video games, but also interacting with their friends through that medium.

urn:contentItem:5WF1-YTC1-JCMP-52F3-00000-00Ciberseguridad, la mayor inquietud de financieros2019-06-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:26ZLexisNexisCiberseguridad, la mayor inquietud de financierosAgencia El Universal


CIUDAD DE MÉXICO, junio 26 (EL UNIVERSAL).- La ciberseguridad y la protección de datos personales son la mayor preocupación de autoridades financieras en torno a los riegos derivados de las fintech, de acuerdo con una encuesta elaborada por el Centro de Estudios Monetarios Latinoamericanos (Cemla). En el ejercicio se destaca el impacto que pueden tener las empresas Big Tech, como Amazon, Apple y Google en los mercados financieros, así como productos disruptivos como las criptomonedas. La encuesta forma parte del estudio Aspectos claves en torno a las Tecnologías Financieras y Regulación, derivado del informe de política que elaboró el grupo de trabajo sobre aspectos regulatorios de las fintech. En el reporte se menciona el caso de México y los puntos más relevantes de la nueva ley fintech.

Sobre lo ciberataques y protección de datos como principales inquietudes que aquejan a los reguladores, industria y bancos centrales en la región, se destaca que pueden estar presentes con mayor o menor intensidad, dependiendo de cada país.
